story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsIn interplanetary news, people across the Earth were glued to their screens as two US astronauts boarded the International Space Station from billionaire Elon Musk#s SpaceX capsule.After a delayed launch earlier in the week, the Dragon crew capsule with Doug Hurley and Bob Behnken on board lted off on Saturday May , carried on the Falcon  rocket.The launch, from Florida’s Kennedy Space Center, was the first into orbit from American soil since  # the year Ella Fyfe was born.Eight-year-old Ella, from Lochgilphead, was among the millions watching and there would be few people outside SpaceX and NASA more enthusiastic.Ella#s mum Lynsey explained: #Ella has always been fascinated with space and to say she was excited would be an understatement. We watched the live launch then the following day we got to watch the docking with the ISS.#With an ambition to go into space herself one day, Ella#s idol is Dave Mackay, chief pilot of Virgin Galactic and former RAF test pilot, who guided SpaceShipTwo, known as VSS Unity, into sub-orbital space in February  before taking her safely back to a runway in the Mojave desert.Dave, from Helmsdale, is the first native-born Scot to go into space and he was kind enough to send Ella a signed photograph.Ella promptly ed the favour, sending the astronaut a signed photograph of herself, signing it: #The future first Scottish GIRL to go into space#.Her dedication to space is such that during lockdown Ella has made it her mission to learn the names of all  of Jupiter#s moons.Signing the photograph, Dave Mackay told Ella #aim high# and that is her plan.Lynsey added: #When she#s been into space as an astronaut, her goal is either to be a NASA scientist or teacher, a science teacher to encourage other little girls.#

title: memories of tarbert herring and almost moving to loch fyne side
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsIn this time of lockdown, I am reminiscing on great times had in Argyll.I first visited Kintyre with my parents as a -year-old, my family having bought a mini car in . We stayed with Margaret and Iain McDonald at their home named Meadowview in Tarbert which was located near the school.We all enjoyed the area so much that we continued to visit every year for the next consecutive eight years.Margaret invited me to go out on the herring boats once or twice. One was named Village Maid and the other Village Belle and, needless to say, we often had kippers for breakfast, which were very nice. I remember there was a boat called the Southern Cross tied up to Cock Island # can anyone tell me any history of it and when it disappeared There also used to be a smokehouse for kippers along from Tarbert to Ardrishaig.Another fond memory I have is watching the logging trucks unloading on the quay and watching them get loaded on to large boats and I think then being shipped round to Sweden or Finland. Is that correct or not as I thought there was a paper mill at Fort William As mentioned earlier, I joined North West Ambulance Service in the s and Margaret used to send me the Argyllshire Advertiser and in one of them was an advert for recruitment to the Scottish Ambulance Service.I duly got an application form from Paisley and was all but sending the form in when I realised it would be very unfair to move so far away from our young children#s grandparents and for them to be unable to see them growing up. At the time your local pharmacist was retiring and my we Sue was a qualied pharmacist, but our children were both under school age so relied on her parents for child care. Ironically, I believe the job was filled with a Blackpool pharmacist whom I had met ocassionally.My love for Scotland continued, and we had our honeymoon travelling around Scotland and calling in at Tarbert for several days on the trip round.Our last trip up there was  in June as a treat from our daughter who accompanied us on this trip. The weather was glorious, and one day we caught the bus to Skipness and walked part of the Kintyre Way back.Another day we took the MacBrayne Ferry to Islay, which was again a glorious day out, also visited Crinan, Lochgilphead and Inveraray, followed by a couple of days fishing off the pier in Tarbert. We travelled back via Portavadie and Dunoon, and have in the past used the ferry to Arran, then Brodick, Ardrossan and home.Thank you for taking the time to read this. It has been good to share some of the memories of Argyll with you.#

title: plans in place for 2021 camanachd cup final
story: Fiona ScottUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsFollowing last week#s expected cancellation of shinty’s  cup competitions, the Camanachd Association has confirmed with title sponsor Tulloch Homes and Kingussie Camanachd Club that the plan to host the final in Kingussie will be postponed for a year and will now take place on September  .The Tulloch Homes Camanachd Cup Final willto the Highland venue for the first time since  and for its th anniversary.First contested in , the final of shinty’s national knock-out cup competition promises to be a brilliant day out for all the family and a  chance to watch two of the country’s elite shinty teams.Hundreds of tickets have already been sold and to be part of this historic moment you can secure your tickets, including some exclusive offers, on shinty.The  final takes place at The Dell and will be one of the biggest stagings of the event in its -year history with live traditional music, entertainment and a dedicated Kids Zone adding to the festival feel.The first final of the Camanachd Cup took place at Inverness on April  . Great interest was centred on the match, played at Needlefield, a piece of ground situated between Longman Road and Cromwell#s Fort, which was described as being #in good condition for the game#.The contending teams were Kingussie and Glasgow Cowal, two brilliant exponents of the game. The day was practically observed as a holiday in Kingussie and the special train which conveyed the team to Inverness brought more than  people to see the contest. From strath and glen, ardent enthusiasts are said to have flocked into the city, the streets of which contained wearers of kilt and knickerbocker galore.Entrance was a shilling and there were around , present. title: gamers-enjoy-e-sports-success-gala-fairydean-rovers
story: A TEAM of online gamers are representing Gala Fairydean Rovers FC in a virtual football competition.Gas engineer Darren Smith, of Galashiels, helped launch an -a-side league on FIFA  in which his hometown club has been enjoying considerable success.Smith, , told the Border : ldquoConsidering itrsquos the first season, itrsquos been excellent ndash and so has the reaction wersquove got from people.The Scottish league, played on a PlayStation , contains a number of teams representing official clubs, including Berwick Rangers, Greenock Morton andEast Stirlingshire.But the Galashiels side has been performing admirably, according to Smith ndash who has his sights set on a lofty finish.ldquoWersquove only beaten twice, said Smith, whose side currently sit third. ldquoLast Sunday we got beaten and we got beaten on the first day of the season.He added: ldquoWersquore still to play the second-placed team and wersquore still to play the team at the top.ldquoI thinkwe go unbeaten and they drop a few points, itrsquos there to be done and Irsquod be happy with second place.A total of  players have signed up to Galarsquos virtual squad, with three players from the town itself.As the recruitment drive was mainly carried out through Twitter, Smith was able to procure the services of gamers from across Britain and further afield. One of the goalkeepers, for instance, lives in Egypt.Asked to describe what it is like playing a video game in co-operation with  other people, Smith indicated it has been a hugely enjoyable experience.He said: ldquoPlaying with  others is sometimes challenging when it comes to getting everyone on for a certain time.ldquoHowever, being manager of the team, I have the luxury of picking who is in the team and I have managed to get some really good guys in who are competitive but also able to enjoy playing the game, which is what its all about in the end.When the real-le football season is in full swing, Smith takes to the park for Lauder Amateur FC.But, for now, the left-back is quite happy plying his trade for Gala online - and he is already considering adding a second tier to the virtual set-up next season.ldquoThe competition gives people a place to go and relax and enjoy themselves without the stresses of les problems, he said.

title: aussie-rugby-player-caring-galashiels-lockdown
story: A KIND-HEARTED Australian rugby player has been delivering food to elderly folk in the Borders town he currently calls home.Gala RFC forward Cody Roman, , moved from Wollongong, New South Wales, in October last year.When coronavirus put paid to his plans to explore more of the Borders, he decided to channel his free time into volunteering as a driver with Food Train.He said: ldquoIrsquom fortunate that Irsquom mobile so I want to get out and help those who are less fortunate or in need."For six weeks, Cody has been dropping off food to residents who are self-isolating.He said: ldquoIt got to the end of winter and I was looking forward to seeing some nice summer days, and then this [lockdown] happened.ldquoThe club put a post on social media askingthere were any guys ready to help out with anything, like shopping or dog-walking or anything that people were unable to do now, for people who had to self-isolate.ldquoThe Food Train commented on the post, and I was like, lsquoIrsquoll do itrsquo. And Irsquove being doing it for six weeks now.ldquoItrsquos been really good ndash everyone appreciates it. Some people who live alone might not have seen anyone for a few days, so theyrsquore very happy when we come out to them and have a chat.ldquoSome of them are very excited and grateful. Some of them offer us a cup of tea and we have to let them down easy."Despite being so far from his home Down Under, Cody is coping well with the coronavirus lockdown.ldquoItrsquos not too bad, with Facebook and social media and stuff. I can just send messages and give people a call."And Irsquom pretty fortunate where I live ndash everyonersquos very friendly.

title: mountain-bikers-told-ride-within-limits-lockdown
story: MOUNTAIN bikers have been issued with guidance during lockdown.Scottish Cyclinghas outlined a series of dos and donts following the Scottish Governments go-ahead for people to exercise more than once a day.There are four rules cyclists and mountain bikers must adhere to under the new SC guidelines:Only ride from your home ndash it is not essential travel to go mountain biking or cycling and you may face enquiries from the policeyou are stopped en route or ing from a ride. All Forestry and Land Scotland car parks and trails, including the stanes sites, remain closedDo not go far ndash whilst you can go exercise for longer, we recommend riding close to where you live and not into remote areas ndash think more smaller loops rather than one longer remote rideRide well within your limits ndash only ride on trails that are that you are very confident you will be able to ride safely and within your competency. It is highly unlikely that mountain rescue are back to full operations ndash consider the fact that a full rescue may not be possible and may take longer to get to youOnly cycle with members of your own household - keep a safe distance when passing other cyclists or pedestrians.Mountain biking trails such as the stanes at Glentress, Peebles, and Innerleithen are closed until further notice to restrict travel to the trails and for safety as they are not being maintained as they were before lockdown.However, walking trails owned by Forestry and Land Scotland are open to members of the public who can access them without using transport.

title: borders-golfers-allowed-play-says-msp
story: BORDERS golfers and anglers should be allowed toto action, according to Rachael Hamilton.The Conservative MSP says she has written to the Scottish Government in a bid to get restrictions lted on outdoor activities.Mrs Hamilton said shooting and angling are among the activities which make an "immense contribution" to the rural economy.She said: "Outdoor sports, such as golfing, hiking and fishing, could take place with the necessary social distancing measures and it would not jeopardise the governmentrsquos efforts in tackling this pandemic."Prime Minister Boris Johnson announced last week that residents in England canto certain outdoor pursuits, including tennis and golf.But the Scottish Government has decided to retain the stay at home message, while now allowing people to exercise more than once a day.Mrs Hamilton, who represents Ettrick, Roxburgh and Berwickshire, says she has written to the Scottish cabinet secretary for rural economy and tourism, Fergus EwingMrs Hamilton, the shadow secretary, said: "We currently have an extraordinary situation in my constituency, around Coldstream, where people can happily fish in the English half of the River Tweed, whilst anglers in Scotland can only watch on from the Scottish side, where fishing is still not permitted at this time."By their nature, outdoor-based sports see participants spread out, whether over a hillside, across an open space or along a river."In the Borders and across rural Scotland, the angling and shooting industry needs to have clarity so it can plan for the new season."I urge the Scottish Government to rethink its restrictions, given the nature of these sports, and the immense contribution they make to our rural economy."

title: selkirk-rugby-players-bid-clean-town
story: HAVING just completed a sponsored charity project that raised almost pound, in under a fortnight for the townrsquos foodbank, Selkirk Rugby Clubrsquos players arenrsquot letting the grass grow under their feet.This week members of the clubrsquos playing squad have embarked on yet another lsquochallengersquo to support the local community ndash litter collection.The idea came from former st XV skipper Ross Nixon, and comes in the wake of a similar venture undertaken by Glasgow Warriorsrsquo professional players.ldquoWhen yoursquore walking in and around Selkirk, you canrsquot help noticing pieces of litter that have been left lying around, often when proper bins arenrsquot that far away, said Nixon.ldquoI thought it would be a good idea for Selkirk players to take a bin bag with them when they head out to take their daily exercise, picking up any litter they see next to paths or along roadside verges.ldquoWersquore lucky in Selkirk to have such unspoilt countryside to exercise in, so itrsquos a shame to see it spoiled by discarded empty bottles, food wrappers and general rubbish.ldquoI kicked off the campaign by nominating three members of our players ndash Aaron McColm, Ewan MacDougall and Liam Cassidy ndash to collect litter on their walks.ldquoEach of this trio will then challenge a further three players to collect litter, and in turn these three will nominate other team-mates, and so on.The project has the backing of Selkirk head coach Scott Wight.He said: ldquoItrsquos another way the club can put something back into the local community, though this time therersquos no sponsorship involved.ldquoItrsquos looking asitrsquos going to be a wee while before any rugby is going to be played, so this latest effort not only helps keep the players in touch with each other, itrsquos also providing a useful service for the Selkirk community.Meanwhile, Selkirk Rugby Club is to stage its annual Players Presentation Night on Fridayndash although this yearrsquos event will be a lsquovirtualrsquo get-together.The plan is for the clubrsquos coaches, players and rugby officials to be digitally linked via Zoom, with Selkirk head coach Scott Wight taking charge of proceedings.ldquoThe idea is to try and stick as closely as possible to the format normally used at the clubrsquos annual presentation nights, said Wight.ldquoA total of nine trophies are up for grabs, and the name of each award winner will be announced separately on the video link, followed by film footage, or photos, of that player in a match situation.ldquoShort addresses will be given by, among others, the clubrsquos chairman and its director of rugby, as well as recaps of the st and lsquoArsquo XVsrsquo seasons by the sidesrsquo respective team managers."It should be a fun evening!

title: rugby-players-hailed-helping-prepare-golf-course
story: GALA rugby players have been thanked for helping to prepare a local golf course for reopening.Torwoodlee Golf Club welcomed members back on Fridayafter First Minister Nicola Sturgeon eased lockdown restrictions.Club chairman Robin Brydon said greenkeepers had been helped by Gala RFC players.He thanked the volunteers for their "great efforts" in rolling turf and raking bunkers.Gala president Ian Dalgleish said: ldquoWersquod be delighted to help other local sports clubs and organisations in these times ndash get in touch."You can contact the rugby club through its Facebook page or by emailing info@galarfc

title: annoyed-borders-mum-accuses-teenagers-ignoring-lockdown
story: A BORDERS mum says groups of young people broke the updated lockdown rules at the weekend.The -year-old woman, who does not wish to be named, says she spotted several large groups failing to obey social distancing in Peebles on Friday evening .She said: ldquoItrsquos frustrating because no-one wants a second wave of this [coronavirus].Since Friday, Scots have been allowed to meet one other household outdoors as long as the total group contains no more than eight people and everyone remains two metres away from each other.However, the mum-of-two says she was ldquoannoyed by what she saw during a walk on Friday at around pm.She says she witnessed ldquofour or five groups of youths flouting the national guidelines as they gathered on the banks of the River Tweed.She said: ldquoThey were all the way along the river and there was no social distancing at all.ldquoThey were obviously there for a bit of a party ndash and there was rubbish everywhere.Most of the people were probably in their late teens, said the woman, adding: ldquoI get that itrsquos really, really hard for them not to see their friends.ldquoBut therersquos a little bit of, lsquoWhere do their parents think they arersquo The woman says she started ringing the police on , but she hung up before getting through to a call handler.Elsewhere over the weekend, Facebook user Scott Brown was disappointed to see rubbish discarded off the Granites Road, near Innerleithen.In his video posted on Sunday morning, he urged residents to pick up any litter they have dropped after social gatherings.He said: ldquoWe want you guys to come and enjoy the countryside and share it with us, butyoursquore going to be doing it, at least be responsible and take all your crap with you when yoursquove finished your fun and games.Mr Brownrsquos video racked up thousands of views and hundreds of comments.

title: borders-teachers-return-schools-next-week
story: TEACHERS in the Borders are due toto school next week.Scottish Borders Councilsays some teaching staff will go back from June  to prepare for classes to restart in August.It comes after First Minister Nicola Sturgeon announced that schools can reopen from August .An SBC spokesperson said: "Some teaching staff willto schools on or around  June, during which time very small numbers of pupils may be able to access schools to support transitions and also school leavers."Our priority is the safety of pupils and staff and we are putting in place the necessary arrangements and will continue to provide updates to parents."

title: study-galashiels-among-safest-places-pandemic
story: GALASHIELS is one of the safest places to live in Scotland during the coronavirus pandemic, according to research.Scotianomics, a think tank, has ranked the countrys  council areas based on the risk of transmitting the virus.Of the  wards in the Borders, Galashiels and District is the safest ndash sitting in th place in the table .Scotianomics founding director Gordon MacIntyre-Kemp said: ldquoThis is nothing to do with the number of cases in an area or how well people living in each area have observed the lockdown.ldquoIt is not a map of COVID- cases across Scotland but of the areas most at risk of community infection."In the Borders, Kelso and District is the most at risk ward , according to the study, with Hawick and Hermitage next , followed by Jedburgh and District .The research, led by senior Samuel MacKinnon, was conducted during April and has been submitted to the Scottish Governmentrsquos Advisory Group on Economic Recovery.Mr MacIntyre-Kemp believes the findings help to argue that lockdown should be lted at dferent speeds in dferent locations.He said: ldquoWhat is evident is that, for a wide iety of reasons, the risks y hugely in dferent communities across Scotland.ldquoIn terms of both the economy and health and wellbeing, we believe it makes sense to ease the lockdown according to those regional dferences in risk.ldquoThere has already been a great deal of debate on whether the four nations within the UK should ease restrictions in lockdown, despite the fact that Oban is likely to have a completely dferent risk profile to Tower Hamlets in London.ldquoWhat our research shows is that there are also signicant iations even within Scotland.He added: ldquoAcross the world, other countries, including China, Italy and Germany, responded to the initial threat on a regionalised basis and are now lting lockdown according to regional iations.ldquoOur research suggests this is the most likely way to prevent a second wave and to protect the economy.The research does not factor in actual infection rates or the fatalities recorded in each area, as the researchers say those figures are not yet publicly available in a sufficiently detailed format.Instead, the study is based on existing data for Scotlandrsquos  local authority wards and calculates each arearsquos risk of exposure according to two factors ndash transmission probability and potential for fatalities.Key information includes population density how many older people or those with underlying health conditions live in the area how many people use road and rail travel how easy it is to access local health services and socioeconomic factors, such as the average income of residents in each area.Scotianomics, created in , aims to analyse the Scottish economy in a way that can help policy makers.The Covid- Risk Monitor can be viewed online at www.scotianomics.org  covid-risk-monitor

title: reaction-borders-mum-accuses-teenagers-ignoring-lockdown
story: SHONA Haslam is urging parents to keep track of their children after a claim that some teenagers broke social distancing rules at the weekend.A mum-of-two reported seeing large groups of teenagersbreaching lockdown guidance in Peebles on Friday evening .Now the leader of Scottish Borders Council has warned residents about the risk of causing a ldquosecond spike of coronavirus cases.Mrs Haslam, a Peebles councillor, said: ldquoI would simply ask all parents to make sure that you know where your kids are and who they are with.The updated lockdown guidance, which came into force on May , allows Scots to meet one other household outdoors, as long as the gathering contains no more than eight people in total and everyone remains two metres apart.The witness account from Friday described several large groups of teenagers gathering along the river, apparently in breach of the lsquoone other householdrsquo instruction ndash as well as the two-metre rule.Asked to comment on the episode, Mrs Haslam said: ldquoUnfortunately over the weekend a small number of young people were being disruptive.ldquoI have spoken to the police and they have increased patrols over the weekend and these will continue.ldquoI would simply ask all parents to make sure that you know where your kids are and who they are with.ldquoIt is really hard for teenagers not seeing their friends for such a long time, but this virus could easily resurge and we all have to stay alert to ensure that we donrsquot get a second spike.Mrs Haslam added: ldquoThe vast majority of our young people are fantastic, sticking by the rules and engaging with their schools and communities.ldquoWe must never fall into the trap of tarring them all with the same brush.ldquoSo [a] massive shout out to all of our young people who are continuing their learning through their schools, and helping contain this virus.Mrs Haslamrsquos Tweeddale East colleague Robin Tatler recommended that constituents phone the police on they spot people breaking lockdown rules.Mr Tatler said: ldquoIt is disappointing to hear that some people in Peebles are acting in an irresponsible way during this dficult time especially as most are not.ldquoIt is important that anyone who witnesses behaviour like this or any other anti-social behaviour should report this using the  number.ldquoThere were a iety of incidents in the town over the past weekend, and I will be asking the Community Action Teams to respond to this.Police Scotlandrsquos Chief Constable Iain Livingstone said on Friday that officers would encourage compliance with the updated lockdown guidance.He said: "We are asking people to take personal responsibility to do the right thing and remember the purpose of these measures is to aid the collective effort to protect the NHS and save lives by preventing the virus from spreading.He added: "We want people to enjoy our outdoor spaces safely and our officers will be robustly tackling crime and anti-social behaviour in our communities."

title: borders-mp-job-losses-jedburgh-devastating-economy
story: BORDERS MP John Lamont says news of possible job losses at a Jedburgh factory is ldquodevastating for the local economy.Coat hanger manufacturer Mainetti announced todaythat up to  workers are at risk of redundancy.Mr Lamont said: ldquoThese job losses in Jedburgh are yet more devastating news for the Borders economy.Mainetti, which is moving operations to Wales, says it intends to sell its Oxnam Road factory to Borders firm Emtelle.Mr Lamont ndash the Conservative representative for Berwickshire, Roxburgh and Selkirk ndash said the economic impact of coronavirus is likely to be ldquosignicant.Reflecting on the Mainetti announcement, he added: ldquoThis will be extremely dficult news for the workers and their families particularly at a time when there is so much uncertainty.ldquoIt is important that the PACE redundancy support is put in place by Scottish Borders Council and the Scottish Government as quickly as possible to give everyone affected all the help they need.ldquoI am also happy to assist any employees affected by this news.ldquoJedburgh urgently needs a stimulus package to boost economic growth in the area to allow it to recover from these signicant job lossesldquoI will be contacting the Scottish Government, the local council and the South of Scotland Economic Partnership to discuss how we can help the town and the wider Borders economy to recover after the impact of the coronavirus.Meanwhile, MSP Rachael Hamilton, also of the Conservatives, said she was very upset to learn about the threat to jobs in Jedburgh.The Holyrood member for Ettrick, Roxburgh and Berwickshire said: ldquoI am devastated to hear of more damaging job cuts.ldquoThe financial impact will hit hard in a fragile rural area like the Borders.ldquoThe Scottish Government must plan now for an economic recovery and try to mitigate further job losses and ensure the people of the Borders can find alternative work opportunities.ldquoI am here to help as best I can, please do get in contactyou, a family member or a relative is affected.Jedburgh councillor Scott Hamilton said: ldquoThe people and businesses of Jedburgh are resilient but it is clear that we are not going to be immune to the impact of coronavirus on our economy.ldquoMainetti has provided good jobs for the people in this area so it will be a real shame to see their manufacturing plant shut.ldquoJedburgh will no doubt recover, but it is important that we get the help we need to be able to attract investment in our town to help economic growth in the future.

title: i-worry-seizure-even-though-medicine-works
story: A GALASHIELS schoolgirl with epilepsy has made a video to teach people about the condition.Lucy Millar gets seizures lasting up to  seconds due to childhood absence epilepsy .Now the nine-year-old wants to teach people how to react when someone has a seizure.Her father Bruce said he felt "pretty emotional" as his daughter crafted a YouTube video, which has gone on to achieve more than , views."Right from the start she wanted to reach as many people as possible to teach them about CAE ," said Mr Millar, whose daughter was diagnosed a year ago.Lucy said: "I feel more OK about it [CAE] because I know more about epilepsy now."Sometimes I worry that Ill have a seizure even though I know my medicine works."I dont think many people know there are dferent types of epilepsy andmore people know about it then its better for epileptics."I would like to teach people what to dosomeone they know has an absence seizure to make sure they are safe."Also to help people spot absence seizures with their children."This newspaper asked Mr Millar what advice he would give parents whose children have epilepsy.He said: "Take a deep breath ndash you might feel like youve been hit by a train, but theres a good chance your child is braver than you realise."He also recommended joining support groups and letting children with epilepsy socialise together.To watch Lucys video, you can click this link.

title: bike-library-helps-key-workers-borders
story: A "BIKE library" has been launched to help key workers during the coronavirus pandemic.Just Cycle and Momentum Scottish Borders, the employability service, started the project at the Tweedbank Craft Centre in March.Key workers have been encouraged to borrow bikes to help them travel to work.Peebles carer Amy, of Walkerburn, said she is "so grateful" for the scheme.She said: "I am much less anxious now as I have a better option to get to work and itrsquos a lot more manageable."I know other carers who would benefit from this and have texted my friend, who is also worried about getting to and from work, to let her know about the bikes."Just Cycle usually gets its recycled bikes from recycling centres around the Borders, but it struggled when the sites were closed.However, the project has been able to meet demand thanks to the kindness of Borders residents.Just Cycle manager Deborah Crozier said: "We put out a call on our Facebook page, requesting donations of unwanted bikes."As always, the Borders community answered our call, donating a further  bicycles."Cycling UK also got in touch to let us know about the Big Bike Revival for Key Workers fund that would allow us to restore more bikes to further support the bike library."We got the funding, and our socially distanced volunteer mechanics ndash Stephen, Andy and Grant ndash have been working flat out to restore, repair and recycle more bicycles."Momentum Scottish Borders Gillian Ormiston said the group received help from cycling product supplier Muc Off.The company provided antibacterial spray and cleaning products to ensure health and safety standards were upheld.Ms Ormiston said: "In my role, it was in my best interests to look at ways to contribute to keeping the Borders on the move."Sustaining and maintaining employment for the Scottish Borders is vital, even more so through this pandemic, to enable key workers to remain focused and on the move, and to support their everyday needs."For more information, visit the Just Cycle Facebook page at: www.facebook justcycle

title: borders-university-staff-make-ppe-key-workers
story: UNIVERSITY staff have made  sets of protective clothing for key workers.Staff at the Heriot-Watt campus, Galashiels, have been sewing scrubs since mid-May.Volunteer Jane Robertson said: "We are very happy to help and feel its our moral obligation to do so."The School of Design and Textiles, which has been using its own stock, plans to make  more sets of scrub.Head of school Fiona Waldron said: "Our staff who have come forward to volunteer have been a great inspiration and they are working hard, in social distancing conditions, to make as many scrubs as they can.ldquoIn these unprecedented timeswe can help even a few, then its worth it.The scrubs are made from  per cent cotton and can also be used after the pandemic, according to the university.The mini workshop was set up by four staff volunteers, who drew up the scrub designs.Ms Robertson said: ldquoWe have been joking that these will be the best-made scrubs in the country, as we are all finding it dficult to let the quality slip in order to sew them faster!The Heriot-Watt team has also been asked to make , cotton face masks for care homes.

title: blackout-tuesday-happening-can-get-involved
story: George Floyd ndash an African-American man ndash was handcuffed and lying face down on a city street as white American Minneapolis police officer Derek Chauvin kneeled on the right side of his neck on May .Chauvinrsquos knee remained there for eight minutes and  seconds, despite Floydrsquos repeated pleas of ldquoI canrsquot breathe ndash two minutes and  seconds of that time occurred after Floyd became unresponsive. He died in custody.The fallout has been far reaching, with dramatic clashes between protesters and police forces in many American cities over the past week.Demonstrations have alsobeen seen in countries across the world, despite much of the planet still under some form of lockdown from coronavirus.Today ndashTuesday,June  ndashmarks#BlackoutTuesday, a day when you will likely notice many of your favourite artists, websites and media outlets going dark across Facebook, Twitter and Instagram.Herersquos everything you need to know:What is #BlackoutTuesday Itrsquos hard to pinpoint exactly where the idea for#BlackoutTuesday comes from, but many are crediting music executivesJamila Thomas and Brianna Agyemang with getting the ball rolling with their#theshowmustbepaused initiative.An official websiteexplains that the social media movement is ldquomeant tointentionally disrupt the work weekhellipin observance of the long-standing racism and inequality that exists from the boardroom to the bouled".The music industry is a multi-billion dollar industry built on privilege, and one that has ldquoprofited prominently from black art.ldquoOur mission is to hold the industry at large, including major corporations and their partners who benefit from the efforts, struggles and successes of Black people accountable, says the website.Despite the name lsquoBlackout Tuesdayrsquo being attribute to it,Thomas and Agyemang say: ldquoThis is not just a -hour initiative. We are and will be in this fight for the long haul."What is happening Major musical artistslike the Rolling Stones, Billie Eilish and Quincy Jones havesaid they will observe the day.No hard and fast lsquorulesrsquo have been set on how to show support for the initiative, but it seems asat the very minimum, bands and artists will be modying their social media profiles, changing cover images and display pictures to the colour black.They will also not be posting across social media channelsa number of artists have also cancelled listening parties or fan events.Spoty will add eight minutes and  seconds of silence to selected playlists and podcasts, reflecting theof timeDerek Chauvin an aggressive knee was applied to the side of George Floyds neck.Major record labels like Def Jam, Interscope, Sony Music, Columbia Records, and more are also expected to participate.,params: .pushMusic-based companies such as Live Nation and TikTok have announced that they will support and stand with the black community.Independent bands and labels from across the world will also be lending their support to this most worthy of causes.Who  is taking part While #TheShowMustBePaused and #BlackoutTuesday originated in the music industry, word of the movement has inevitably spread.Now representatives across many dferent industries from entertainment and beyond are lending their support to the cause.Celebrities from the world of film and TV have also vowed to take part, and in America, a number of television networks will go dark for eightminutes and  seconds in honour of Floyd.MTV ldquowill not hold any meetings nor conduct any businesshellip in solidarity with our African American colleagues and loved ones across the country, according toChris McCarthy, president of the ViacomCBS Entertainment  Youth Group.How can I get involved There are a number of ways you can get involved and show your support for #BlackoutTuesdayand the Black Lives Matter movement.Blacking out your social media profiles is a first step, buttheshowmustbepausedlists further suggestions as to how you can make a dference, and enact positive change:If you have been impacted by the recent events, take a break - there is a lot going on and sometimes we all just need a minute. Take that minute...Help the family of George Floyd -www.gofundme f georgefloydFight for Breonna Taylor -justiceforbreonna.org Help the family of Ahmaud Arbery -www.gofundme f i-run-with-maudWant to help protesters  Donate to one or more community bail funds -https:secure.actblue donate bail_funds_george_floydVisit Movement For Black Lives for additional ways you can help the cause -mbl.orgWant to connect with leaders building grass roots campaigns  -www.untilfreedom

title: martin-lewis-issues-important-advice-homeowners-mortgage-holidays
story: Martin Lewis has released important advice on mortgages for all homeownersacross the country.The MoneySavingExpertshared informationon three-month mortgage holidays, which follows an update bytheFinancial Conduct Authority .What has Martin said Martin said: "Under the regulators plans, you willhave untilOctober to apply for one, and those who have already had one can extend."Yet interest racks up and it can impact you creditworthiness."My hope is that as these holidays are specically for the short-term financial hit of coronavirus,and as the practice is so widespread, it wont be used by many firms, and where it is it wont tarnish iniduals credit reputation for too long."But theres no real way to know. Most importantly, I dont believe this should stop anyone who needs a mortgage holiday from getting one."If its crucial for cash flow, just do it."Yet for those on the border, who may find it temporarily useful but can cope without it, add this to the fact that interest racks up during the payment holiday and Id err on the side of caution."What have the FCA said Christopher Woolard, interim chief executive at the FCA, said: "Our expectations are clear - anyone who continues to need help should get help from their lender."We expect firms to work with customers on the best options available for them, paying particular attention to the needs of their vulnerable customers, and to provide information on where to access help and advice."Where consumers can afford to restart mortgage payments, it is in their best interests to do so. But where they cant, a range of further support will be available."People who are struggling and have not had a payment holiday will continue to be able to apply until October ."What have UK Finance said Stephen Jones, the CEO of UK Finance, said: "Banks and building societies will continue to help their customers get through the crisis and have a wide range of support available."Anyone with concerns about their financial situation should check with their lender to discuss which form of support would be the best choice for them."

title: mcdonalds-galashiels-site-reopens-drive-thru
story: McDONALDS in Galashiels has reopened its drive-thru service after closing due to the coronavirus pandemic.Safety measures are in place at the Wilderhaugh site, which is running with reduced staff.The drive-thru opened at am today with a limited menu.McDonalds says it expects a "high demand" at all of its reopened sites.The fast food chain has issued a list of the safety measures being rolled out.These are the new measures at McDonaldsSocial distancing in kitchens and service areasPerspex screens at drive-thru windowsProtective equipment for staffFloor markings in the premisesAll staff will be asked to confirm they are healthy and able to work andcontactless thermometers will be used to take employees temperatures on arrival for every shtRestaurants willwith smaller teams, offering a limited menuand operating reduced hoursEncouraging capped spendat pound per order, with customers encouraged to pay by contactless methodsDrive-thru customers can browse the menu, order and pay ahead using the My McDonaldrsquos app

title: scots-urged-take-knee-doorsteps-solidarity-george-floyd-tonight
story: People across Scotland are being asked to show their solidarity with George Floyd on their doorsteps this evening as protests in America continue.Anti-racism campaigners Stand Up to Racism are urging people to take the knee on Wednesday night in a socially-distanced protest in response to the death of Floyd, who died in police custody.The -year-old died last week after a police officer held him down by pressing his knee into his neck.The US has since erupted in riots from people demanding justice, and other countries across the world have begun to take action.People in the UK are being asked to kneel at their doorsteps at pm on Wednesday.They say the demonstration has been inspired by the kneeling protests first staged by American football star Colin Kaepernick in .ldquoWe send our condolences, and stand in solidarity with all those demanding justice right now from deaths resulting from contact with the policemdashfrom Minnesota to Kirkcaldy," said Talat Ahmed, STUCs Scotland Convenor."As we demand justice for George Floyd we also remember Sheku Bayoh, who like Floyd said, I cant breathe, while being brutally restrained by police five years ago here in Scotland."We welcome the First Ministers support for the Black Lives Matter movement. But we also support the call from the Scottish Trades Union Congresss Black Workers Committee on the Scottish government for more openness about the impact of coronavirus on BAME communities here in Scotland."We call on Scottish MPs to back the EDM at Westminster for a public inquiry into the disproportionate impact of Covid- on BAME communities."Several protests had been organised throughout Scotland, however First Minister Nicola Sturgeon advised protesters to avoid large groups.Ms Sturgeon backed the Black Lives Matter movement, saying she sympathised with those looking to protest, but warned of the risks involved with gathering due to the ongoing coronavirus pandemic.She said: "Right now, it is the case, unfortunately, and regrettably, that large gatherings of people could pose a risk to health and indeed to le."Unfortunately, thats the case whether it is a peaceful protest or a football match or any other gathering where people are coming together in close proximity."What I would say to those who want to protest, and I say this as an ally and supporter, is that we need to find ways of allowing people to make their voices heard and to make the points that many of us want to be made and to be heard right now but to do so in a way that is safe and is not putting people protesting or wider communities at risk."

title: ibuprofen-tested-possible-treatment-reduce-covid-19-symptom
story: Scientists have begun a new trial to determine whether ibuprofen might hold the key to preventing severe breathing problems inCOVID- patients.Heres what you need to know.Why has the new trial started Experts are assessing whether a special formulation of thedrug could help reduce the serious side effect seen among patients infected withcoronavirus.It is hoped that the cheap anti-inflammatory drug could reduce severe respiratory illness when delivered at a certain point tohospital patients.This could potentially lead to shorter hospital stays and fewer patients needing help in intensive care units .The trial is for hospitalised patientsMitul Mehta, professor of neuroimaging and psychopharmacology and director of Centre for Innovative Therapeutics at Kings College London, told the PA news agency: ldquoItrsquos a trial for patients with COVID- disease to seegiving them an anti-inflammatory drug ndash a specic form of ibuprofen ndash will reduce the respiratory problems they have.He stressed that the trial was for hospitalised patients ndash not those who have mild or suspected COVID-.Participants will be drawn from those who are hospitalised, but not so ill they are in need of intensive care.ldquoAndwe can reduce their symptoms at that stage we have a number of benefits: we could reduce the amount of time that someone spends in hospital ndash they might recover quicker and go home, thatrsquos obviously a fantastic outcome we also might be reducing the degree of respiratory distress so that it can be managed in the hospital setting, without needing to go to ICU. And that is a fantastic outcome as well.ldquoTheoretically, this treatment, given at this time, should be beneficial.ldquoBut of course, this is based on animal studies. Itrsquos based on case reports, we need to do a trial to show that the evidence actually matches what we expect to happen.What have other studies found so far Prof Mehta said that animal studies into acute respiratory distress syndrome ndash a symptom of COVID- disease ndash showthat about  per cent of animals with this condition die.But when they are given this special formulation of ibuprofen, the survival rates increase to  per cent.ldquoThis is very promising, he added. ldquoBut of course it is an animal study, so we want to translate that really compelling result into humans.How will the trial work The Liberate trial is a joint effort between experts from Guyrsquos and St Thomasrsquo NHS Foundation Trust, Kingrsquos College London and the pharmaceutical organisation the SEEK Group.Half of the patients enrolled in the trial will receive standard care and the other half will receive standard care plus the special ibuprofen formulation.,params: .pushIt is hoped that the way the drug has been formulated will reduce potential gastric side effects linked to ibuprofen.Professor Matthew Hotopf, director of the NIHR Maudsley Biomedical Research Centre, said: ldquoThis highly innovative therapeutic approach seeks to rapidly advance a potentially important new treatment."If successful, the global public health value of this trial result would be immense given the low cost and availability of this medicine.Early on in the pandemic, there was controversy over the use of ibuprofen after a French health minister advised against the use of it.Scientists in Britain launched a review to assess ties to the drug and COVID-.The Commission on Human Medicinesrsquo expert working group concluded: ldquoThere is currently insufficient evidence to establish a link between use of ibuprofen and susceptibility to contracting Covid- or the worsening of its symptoms.

title: peebles-callants-keep-town-looking-good-annual-clean
story: DESPITE this years Beltane Festival being cancelled due to coronavirus, the Callants still turned out to keep Peebles clean and "looking good".Around  volunteers gathered on Sundayat am to remove weeds and litter across central areas of the town.The clean-up, held before the Beltane each year, collected more than  bags of weeds this time round.The High Street, Eastgate, Northgate and the Old Town were all looked after by the volunteers, who were armed with garden tools, gloves and high-vis vests.Chief Callant Andrew Williamson told the Peeblesshire News: "This year, because of lockdown, council workers are not out, so the town has more weeds than usual."We had one or two comments online so we brought the clean-up forward."We would usually do it the Sunday before Beltane."Mr Williamson, , said Tweed Bridge and Cuddy Bridge also received the clean-up treatment a fortnight ago.He added that after both events, the town is now "looking good".Across the Borders, summer festivals have been cancelled, including West Lintons Whipman Play and Innerleithens St Ronans Border Games.The Chief Callant described how he felt about the cancellation of this years celebrations.He said: "Its disappointing, but there is not much we can do."The last time the festival stopped was probably World War Two."But every festival is the same. Well have to come back next year bigger and better than before."Updates on the Beltane Festival  can be found on the festivals Facebook page at: www.facebook PeeblesBeltaneFestival

title: tourists-slammed-driving-borders-making-diy-loo
story: CITY residents have been accused of showing a ldquocomplete disregard for Peebles by travelling to the town and breaching lockdown rules.The chairman of Peebles Community Council says visitors from Edinburgh were spoken to by police at the weekend.Les Turnbull said: ldquoI am disappointed that the police did not take more positive action to prosecute these offenders.Relaxed lockdown measures were introduced last Friday , allowing Scots to meet up with one other household outdoors as long as the total gathering contains no more than eight people and everyone stays two metres apart.Travelling short distances for leisure and exercise is permitted, with First Minister Nicola Sturgeon recommending that no-one goes further than five miles from their home.However, Mr Turnbull says police spoke to visitors from Edinburgh at the weekend after reports that three vehicles had parked up in Hay Lodge Park, Peebles, next to Fotheringham Bridge.Mr Turnbull said: ldquoIt would appear that the occupants of these vehicles had removed the chain securing the gate in South Parks Industrial Estate to gain access before parking up and erecting what appeared to be a makesht toilet behind a screen.Police are understood to have issued advice to the group, who claimed they had found the gate open. They packed up and left soon after being spoken to.Mr Turnbull said: ldquoIt beggars belief that these visitors from Edinburgh feel they can drive to Peebles, go through a gate which is chained, and park up on what is clearly park land.ldquoTo then erect what seems to be a toilet on the grass near Fotheringham Bridge really is a step too far.ldquoWhere any of this human waste was dumped, is a question I would like answering.Mr Turnbull says he has asked council officials to make sure the gate is secured with a ldquoheavy padlock.The community leader believes misbehaving visitors are guilty of showing a ldquocomplete disregard for the regulations and the people of Peebles.He added: ldquoAs the town begins to recover from this crisis, we do want and need visitors to come and enjoy what we have to offer, but is it too much to ask for them to be respectful and responsible Chief Inspector Stuart Reid said: "The current regulations are clear: people should only leave the house for very limited purposes, for example for basic necessities, for exercise or recreation, for medical needs or travelling for work which cannot be done from home."We are asking people to take personal responsibility to do the right thing and remember the purpose of these measures is to aid the collective effort to protect the NHS and save lives by preventing the virus from spreading."Our officers will continue to engage with the public, explain the legislation and guidance and encourage compliance."We will use enforcement as a last resort only where there is a clear breach of the legislation."

title: strawberry-moon-2020-time-see-skies-uk
story: The UKis to be graced by a Strawberry Moon this week in a rare lunar event that will lightup the skies.The Strawberry Moon coincideswith summer solstice once every  years when the moon is situated on the opposite side of the Earth as the Sun - whichfully illuminates its round shape.Unfortunately, despite its fruity name, the moon may notappear in warm colours as we would expect.The lunar event got its name fromNative American tribes, who used the moon to help them indicate when fruit would be ripened.What does NASA say about the Strawberry Moon As described by NASA: ldquoThe Maine Farmers Almanac first published Indian names for the full moons in the s.ldquoAccording to this almanac, the full moon in June or the last full Moon of spring is known as the Strawberry Moon, a name universal to just about every Algonquin tribe.ldquoThe name comes from the relatively short season for harvesting strawberries in northeastern North America.The Strawberry Moon has also been referred to as the Hot Moon.So, when can I see it You can expect to see the spectacular lunar event at about .pm BST on Friday evening.According to the Royal Greenwich Observatory in London, the Strawberry Moon will last for up to three tofour days.

title: coronavirus-make-face-mask
story: YOUVE probably heard by now that wearingface coverings in Scotlands public placescould become mandatory in the future.First Minister Nicola Sturgeon confirmed this was under consideration in her daily briefing yesterday, but stressed there is no timescale on when the wearing of one mightenforced across the country.Ms Sturgeon was keen to emphasise medical face masks should be prioritised for frontline workers and instead has encouraged Scots to make their own face coverings from home.Whether you are handy with a Singer or just want a quick fix, there are so many ways you can make sure you are protected.Heres our guide to dferent types and step-by-step instructions on how to make them.What do I need to make a face covering There are many dferent materials you can use to protect yourself and stop the spread of Covid- to those around you.This ranges from bandanas, to t-shirts, fabrics, to string. The important thing is you should be able to find most of these items in your home already.Think of this as a good chance to finally find a use for that t-shirt in the back of the cupboard youve been meaning to take to a charity shop for as long as you can remember.You dont need to be an expert in sewing machines to make your own face covering Well show you how to make some coverings in the next section, but here are some of the items you will need to make one:Elastic band or hair tiesBandanaHandkerchiefT-shirtScissorsKitchen towelPinsNeedle and threadWhat are the dferent types of home-made face coverings and how can I make one The UK government advises washing your hands or using hand sanitiser before putting on and after taking off face coverings.You should also:Avoid touching your eyes, nose, or mouth at all timesStore used face coverings in a plastic bag until you have an opportunity to wash themWash a face covering regularly - it can go in with other laundry, using your normal detergentThe one with the bandanaOkay. Not many of us will have a spare bandana sitting around butyou do they are an easy way to make an effective covering.For this youll need: Elastic ties or hairpins, and your bandana. Thats it.Step one: Lay the cloth out flatStep two: Fold in halfStep three: Fold top third down, fold bottom up to meet itStep four: Thread through two elastic bandsStep five: Fold each side to the middle and tuck into the foldsThe one with the t-shirtHave a look in your cupboard. Wed bet you have at least one old t-shirt which either doesnt fit or looked more at home in a Wham video than .Well, now is the perfect time to say goodbye and recyle your old shirt for good.,params: .pushHeres what youll need: An old t-shirt, scissors, kitchen towel, pinsStep one: Draw pattern across arms and body of t-shirtStep two: Cut along patterns so you have two layers from front and back of t-shirtStep three: Pin one sideSteph four: Inset non-woven fabric material such as a paper towelStepfive: Pin other sideSteph six: Tie at back so it is tight across the nose and tight under the chinThe one that needs sewingThis is one for the wannabe sewing bees. Dust off that Singer and have a go and youll have an effective face covering in no time.Heres what youll need: A sewing machine, needle and thread, scissors, elastic, towel, fabricStep one: Cut two cloth rectangles cmxcmStep two: Place on top of each other, waysStep three: Fold over the top of the fabric .cm and stitch all the way acrossStep four: Fold the bottom up and stitch .cm inwards from the edge of either side - this will create a filter pocketStep five: Folder the shorter sides inwards about cm and stitch - leaving a gap to thread elasticStep six: Thread a cm piece of elastic through the hem on one side and tie the ends. Repeat on the other sideStep seven: Put kitchen paper inside as filterVisit here for more guidance from the UK Government.We have also used information from the Centre for Disease Control and Prevention .

title: borders-builder-saves-35-jobs-bank-loan
story: A BORDERS builder has saved  jobs after receiving a six-figure loan.Melroses Rural Renaissance Ltd , the parent company of JS Crawford, put  full-time staff on furlough due to the coronavirus shutdown.But the workers futures are now safe after Bank of Scotlandagreed to issue a loan.The banks relationship director Douglas Spowart said: "The funding has secured the future of the business alongside the jobs of its  members of staff.JS Crawford Group is one of the largest builders in the region, with sites in Melrose, Kelso and Galashiels.RRL managing director Michael Crawford said: ldquoWe were set for further success this year until the COVID- crisis hit."As with many other businesses, much of our activity is now on hold.ldquoThe financial support means wersquove been able to pay our suppliers and support our staff.ldquoWersquore a big part of the community here, so itrsquos really important to us as a company that wersquore able to meet our commitments.Once lockdown has ended, the firm aims to start three projects in the Borders.Seven large houses are planned for Orchard Park, Gattonside, while Galashiels is due to see a mix of detached and semi-detached homes at the Old Tennis Courts on Abbotsford Road.Luxury flats and a health spa, planned for Melrose, are awaiting planning permission.Mr Crawford said the bank has helped RRL through "cash flow challenges, ensuring we have the financial headspace needed to continue to trade".Mr Spowart, of the bank, added: ldquoWersquove worked with RRL to put a package in place that, critically, the business can afford to repay."RRL achieved a turnover of pound million in .

title: borders-urged-stay-within-five-miles-home
story: BORDERS residents are being reminded that they should stay within five miles of their home under the updated lockdown guidance.Scottish Borders Council chief executive Tracey Logan has thanked people for staying at home as much as possible during the coronavirus pandemic.But Ms Logan is urging households to remain within five miles of their front doorthey do travel for exercise or recreation.She said: ldquoWhile we have so many beautul places to visit in our region, Id strongly advise everyone to follow the national guidelines by not travelling more than five miles from your home.Lockdown rules were relaxed slightly on May , meaning people can now meet up with one other household outside, as long as the total gathering contains no more than eight and everyone follows social distancing guidelines.Ms Logan said: ldquoWhile we can now enjoy slightly more freedom, Irsquod still encourage you to stay at home as much as possible to help limit the spread of the virus.Meanwhile, NHS Borders chief executive Ralph Roberts also thanked residents for obeying guidelines so far.He said this has helped drive down the number of virus patients in the region, adding that the health board has ldquosignicantly reduced the number of beds set aside for such patients.However, Mr Roberts said circumstances can ldquoeasily change.He said: "COVID- has already claimed too many lives and we all have a responsibility to ensure that we do everything we can do to protect our local community, family and friends.The full statement from Tracey Logan"Weve only been able to reach this stage thanks to our residents staying at home, only making essential journeys, observing social distancing guidelines and washing their hands regularly."I want to thank everyone for playing their part."We can now meet up with other households outdoors and I know families and friends across the Borders have been making the most of the opportunity to see each other again."You do still need to keep at least two metres apart, though, stay outdoors, and wash your hands regularly."People are now allowed to sit in parks and open areas, and travel within their local area for exercise or recreation."While we have so many beautul places to visit in our region Id strongly advise everyone to follow the national guidelines by not travelling more than five miles from your home.ldquoWhile we can now enjoy slightly more freedom Irsquod still encourage you to stay at home as much as possible to help limit the spread of the virus.ldquoWe have been able to ease restrictions on some services such as reopening community recycling centres but other council facilities such as playparks and public toilets remain closed.ldquoI also know residents who are currently shielding are being asked to remain at home for the time being."I realise the sacrices these people are having to make but would like to reassure them that we will continue to give them all the support they need."Our Community Assistance Hubs can provide help with food, shopping and delivery of medication as well as regular check-ins to see that everything is okay."If anyone needs support please visit our website or call   .The full statement from Ralph RobertsldquoI would like to take the opportunity to thank everyone in the Borders for the co-operation you have shown over the last two months in following the guidance on lockdown and restriction of movement."All of us in the NHS are very conscious that this has been dficult and will have had a lasting impact on many people in our community."However, I am pleased to emphasise that this has worked so far and as a local NHS we have been able to care for all the COVID patients we have seen, whether that was in the community or for those more seriously ill in hospital."I am also pleased to advise that over the last month we have seen a steady reduction of patients in hospital who have had or been suspected of having COVID."We have therefore now signicantly reduced the number of beds set aside for COVID patients."However I recognise that this can easily change and I would therefore encourage everyone to continue to follow the Scottish Government advice as we ease lockdown.,params: .push"Please also remember to follow the advice on hand hygiene, physical distancing and self-isolationyou or a family member is experiencing any symptoms of the virus."COVID- has already claimed too many lives and we all have a responsibility to ensure that we do everything we can do to protect our local community, family and friends."We are now working hard to look at how we can reintroduce the services we needed to pause while we responded to COVID."Because of the continuing risk with COVID this will mean though that some of our services will be provided dferently so that we can keep our patients and staff safe."I would therefore ask that you follow any information or requests that are madeyou need to attend one of our healthcare premises."Please remember that the NHS is open and should you have any concerns about your health please do not hesitate to contact us through the normal routes."UPDATE -.pm, June , -The title: many-key-workers-borders

title: staff-face-redundancy-top-borders-hotel
story: STAFF at a leading Borders hotel are at risk of losing their jobs.Crieff Hydro Group, which operates the four-star Peebles Hydro, has announced that  jobs are under threat across its portfolio.The grouprsquos chief executive Stephen Leckie says he is ldquopersonally devastated for everyone who could lose their job.As reported by our sister newspaper The Herald, Mr Leckie said coronavirus has had a ldquodrastic impact on his hotels.He said: "When we closed our doors at the end of March, it was one of the darkest days in our  year history and this is another.ldquoThe impact coronavirus has had on our industry and business has been immediate and drastic.ldquoAs a family-run business built on the strength of our people, discussing potential redundancies is the toughest step wersquove ever had to consider.ldquoI am personally devastated for every one of our team who could lose their job."The Crieff Hydro Group says it will start a consultation with affected staff in August.

title: glasgow-set-enter-lockdown-phase-2-next-week---changes
story: NICOLA Sturgeon has confirmed todayshe is "optimistic" that Scotland will be able to enter Phase  of the routemap out of lockdown next week.The First Minister said morecoronavirus lockdown measures are set to be eased "at least in part" at the next formal review on June .At the Scottish Governmentdaily briefing, Ms Sturgeonsaid: "I am optimistic that,  days from now at the next formal review, we will be able to move, at least in part, into the next phase of our routemap out of lockdownwith more inidual freedoms restored and more businesses able to open up and operate again."But that depends on each and every one of us, so please, please, stick with it for now."It comes as figures shows for a second day in a row there were no new deaths reported overnight in Scotland.This comes with the message of caution, with fewer deaths usuallyrecorded over the weekends.Nicola Sturgeon optimistic of entering Phase  next weekWhat can change next week While not all of these may take place, these are some of the measures set out in the routemap out of lockdown for Phase .Seeing friends and familyFrom June , people in Scotland may be able to meet people from other households indoors for the first time - while maintaing physical distancing and hygiene measures.You will also be able to meet with larger groups including family and friends outside.Shopping and pubsFrom Phase , the Scottish Government says pubs and restaurants can open outdoor spaces such as beer gardens - as long as social distancing measures can be maintained.Outdoor markets can also reopen, provided there can be controls on the number of people within the market and distancing is kept.Previously closed small retail units can also reopen - again with the underlying pin of physical distancing.SportsThe resumption of professional sport, in line with public health advice, is currently planned for Phase .Likewise,sports courts and playgrounds may also be able toreopen from this date.However gyms will not be able to reopen until Phase .Weddings and worshipIt is hoped that under Phase , marriages and civil partnerships can take place in Scotland with minimal number of attendees.The routemap also says places of worship will be able to reopen for private prayer - but not for extended groups until Phase .TransportPeople may be able to drive locally for leisure under the Phase  routemap.Public transport can increase their capacity but will remain signicantly limited to allow for physical distancing.WorkingWorking from home remains the default position.But the guidance says non-essential indoor, non-office based workplaces can reopen - title: no-sense-loss-dundas-statue-removed
story: The leader of Edinburgh City Council has said he would feel ldquono sense of lossa statue of a politician who delayed the abolition of slavery was removed.Henry Dundas, st Viscount Melville, worked to frustrate efforts to end the trade by using his influence as home secretary, setting the move back  years.A ft column with a statue of the politician ndash known as the Melville Monument ndash stands in St Andrew Square and was vandalised during the Black Lives Matter protest in the Scottish capital on Sunday.Council leader Adam McVey told BBC Radio Scotlandrsquos Good Morning Scotland programme: ldquoI would have absolutely no sense of lossthe Dundas statue was removed and replaced with something  or left as a plinth.ldquoI think itrsquos important to tell our story as a city, I think itrsquos important that thatrsquos reflective, thatrsquos representative of what actually happened ndash not what we might have wanted to happen ndash and I think we take that conversation from there.Dundas put forward an amendment to a Bill which would abolish slavery in , opting for a more gradualist approach.This allowed the practice to continue for  years longer than it otherwise would have done.During this time an estimated , people were transported to Britain as slaves.Dundas was nicknamed ldquothe Great Tyrant and was later impeached for the misappropriation of public money in .The now A-listed monument was erected in .The bronze memorial to Edward Colston situated in Bristol city centre since , was torn down after crowds left College Green as part of a Black Lives Matter demonstration pic tXjiuamdash PA MediaJune , Mr McVeyrsquos comments came after campaigners pulled down the statue of slave trader Edward Colston in Bristol and graffiti was scrawled on the monument to Sir Winston Churchill in Londonrsquos Parliament Square.Talks are ongoing to discuss the wording of a plaque that will be installed at the monument to display a more ldquorepresentative history.Mr McVey said: ldquoWhen we scratch beneath the surface of our cityrsquos long history ndash the sweeping streets of the New Town, some of the statues in our squares ndash we must face an uncomfortable truth.ldquoEdinburgh was, in part, built on wealth created by the slave trade.ldquoFor too long this part of our cityrsquos history has been hidden but we are starting to confront our past and need to go further.He added: ldquoThe statue of Henry Dundas in St Andrew Square at the very least requires a more representative story to be told on-site and, although the statue doesnrsquot belong to the council, wersquove previously done what we can to facilitate discussions around how this might look.ldquoWhile a consensus wasnrsquot achieved with a previous approach, we need a resolution now to make a change and I have called a meeting of Edinburgh World Heritage, Prof Geoffrey Palmer and an expert from the University of Edinburgh with a view to agreeing a new form of words as quickly as possible.On Tuesday, London Mayor Sadiq Khan announced the cityrsquos landmarks would be reviewed to ensure they reflect the capitalrsquos ersity.He said the title: black-lives-matter-every-scottish-street-linked-slave-trade-revealed
story: SCOTLANDrsquoS shameful ties to the slave-trade have been highlighted in an interactive map.Black Lives Matter protests across the globe have thrust our nationrsquos history into the spotlight once again ndash with thousands taking to our streets and parks to join calls from around the world for racial equality.The catalyst for the growing unrest: the death of -year-old black man George Floyd in Minnesota, when a white police officer knelt on his neck for more than eight minutes.And with support growing in Scotlaandfor the renaming of streets linked to the slave-trade, research from the University College Londonhas revealed the true extent of Scotlandrsquos dark ties.The death of George Floyd has sparked mass protestsAcross the country, more than  addresses which benefited from the money in the slave-trade have been identied.Edinburgh proved to be a major benefactor in the list ndash with more than  addresses highlighted.In Glasgow, just under  places were noted in the list, with  in both Ayrshire and the Borders.There were  cases in Fe, with a further  in Stirling and  in Inverclyde, West Dunbartonshire and Argyll and Bute.BLM protests took place across Scotland over the weekendAcross the UK, there are , addresses listed on the map.As the researchers from the UCLs Centre for the Study of the Legacies of British Slave-ownership note: "Each address pinpoints a slave-owner or direct beneficiary in a particular place at a specic time."You can view the interactive map HEREwith all the locations listed by the UCL.You can find out more information about the address and occupiers past by clicking on the blue markers.Follow the link above to view the interactive map

title: mcdonalds-glasgow-set-open-walk-ins-month---
story: McDonaldrsquos bosses have revealed when their Scotland stores will reopen for walk-ins.Following a closed test in London last month,  service station locations on UK motorways will open for takeaway from Wednesday, June .Then, from June onwards, they will gradually roll-out to high streets, towns and city centres.The fast-food chain also plan a trialled relaunch of the McDonaldrsquos breakfast service from that date.McDonaldrsquos UK  Ireland CEO Paul Pomroy said: ldquoWersquore delighted to be back.ldquoI am extremely proud of our employees, franchisees and suppliers who are working so hard in so many communities already.ldquoThe high street is at the heart of our business, it is where we started in the UK, in Woolwich over  years ago.ldquoIn line with Government changes to lockdown restrictions, over the next few weeks and months wersquoll reopen on high streets across the UK and in towns and cities in Ireland.ldquoI know that opening those doors will be incredibly satisfying for our restaurant teams, but it will also mean them getting used to the measures we have implemented to enable us to safely .ldquoSo please continue to support them and follow the social distancing measures wersquove introduced for the safety of our teams and you.What do McDonaldrsquos say about new safety measures -We will provide clear signposting and floor-markings to create a one-way system around our restaurants for you and our delivery partner couriers-We will only allow certain numbers of people inside our restaurants at a time to help you and us adhere to social distancing ndash this will y depending upon the restaurant size and lay-out-When you visit us for takeaway, we will welcome you inside when a space becomes available, and wersquoll ask you to sanitise your hands at the cleaning stations we are introducing in all restaurants-We will have fewer self-order screens switched on and will sanitise those in use at least every  minutes. You can also order via the My McDonaldrsquos app-If you can visit alone to collect your food, please do so, however we know this isnrsquot always possible ndash children are of course still welcome, but for now wersquoll be putting away our crayons and colouring sheets and keeping the play areas and digital play areas closed-Our seating areas, customer toilets and lts will remain closed-As our dining areas will not be open, our recycling points will also remain closed but most of our packaging can be recycled so please do dispose of it responsibly and recycle wherever possible when you get home-To help protect our employees and other customers, we ask you not to visityou feel unwell.
