title: community-resilience-volunteers-aberlady-cockenzie-port-seton-gullane-prestonpans
story: From collecting shopping and vital prescriptions to dog walking and simply being there for people, the volunteers are there for residents throughout the coronavirus crisis.Here, we look at fourof the groups who are giving up their own time to help out.Aberlady. Picture: Google MapsAberladyVOLUNTEERS are continuing to do what they can to offer support to vulnerable and elderly members of the community in Aberlady.Aberlady Resilience has dealt with about  requests for help during the coronavirus pandemic.Resilience group member Ian Malcolm told the Courier they continued to be there for people in need of assistance. He said: ldquoWe are not particularly aware of anybody having any particular problems.ldquoWe have got a fair number of volunteers and there are messages being delivered every day.ldquoIt is all small scale stuff.Contact detailsAnyone needing help should contact either Ian Malcolm on   or Sam Robertson on  . Further information is available online at www.facebook Aberlady-Resilience-Cockenzie and Port Seton. Picture: Google MapsCockenzie and Port SetonTHE resilience effort in Cockenzie and Port Seton continues to help those in need in the community, and is on the lookout for more dog walkers.The effort is being led by the local community council, whose chairman Bryan Hickman said that those who wish to volunteer as dog walkers should contact the emergency resilience number on  .Anyone who needs assistance of any kind is also asked to contact this number.As well as collecting prescriptions and helping with shopping, staff and volunteers at the Port Seton Centre have made and delivered food packages and hot meals.So far almost , meals have been handed out.The resilience team has also been supporting the work of the local school hubs, with crafts packs going out to families alongside breakfast packs.Lunch packs continue to be provided to children who would usually receive free school meals.People are reminded that the sports pitches at the Port Seton Centre remain closed, and fall under phase two of the Scottish Governmentrsquos plan to ease lockdown restrictions.In the past week, spaghetti bolognese cooking packs, including onions picked from the Seed-to-Plate initiative, have been delivered to families in the Preston Seton Gosford area .The PSG Area Partnership has thanked the East Lothian Council Connected Communities administration staff who helped to pay for  families to receive cooking packs for two weeks.A pantry at Port Seton Centre is open pm-pm MondayFriday for those needing food, toiletries or pet food.Those who wish to attend are asked to social distance and wait for a member of staff to assist them.Delivery enquiries can also be made by calling  .Contact detailsThose who require assistance of any kind are asked to call the resilience emergency number on  .Gullane. Picture: Google MapsGullaneVOLUNTEERS throughout Gullane have vowed to continue offering services to people in need, despite lockdown restrictions easing.The Gullane Resilience Team has been working hard throughout the coronavirus pandemic to assist anyone in the village who is vulnerable.A spokesman for the group said that would be continuing, and told the Courier: ldquoWith Scotland entering stage one of the exit strategy, we will still be continuing with all our activities but at the same time planning for the changes required at each of the following stages, in addition to the effect on the pool of volunteers available.ldquoOnce again, our thanks go to the many volunteers who have given so much of their time.The pool of volunteers deal with referrals and requests for the uplt of prescriptions.Every Tuesday, from .am to .am, and on Fridays from noon to pm, in the village hall there is a ldquohub.The group spokesman said: ldquoWe have our food distribution, DVD, book and jigsaw exchange plus ious types of bread flours and yeast for sale for the bakers in the community.ldquoLorna Scott, Amy Irvine, Rachel Wallace and Sue Bryce have been very busy making weekly, themed craft packs which are freely available for children in the village and are proving very popular.ldquoFabric face coverings made by the Gullane Scrubbers are also available ndash with donations going towards the East Lothian Foodbank.Contact detailsFor more information, call   or email Gullanerteam@gmailInformation can also be found at www.gullanert and by searching on Facebook for Gullane RT.Prestonpans. Picture: Google MapsPrestonpansPRESTONPANS Community Council chairperson Brian Weddell has appealed to people to stick to the lockdown guidelines, after a weekend which saw people travel from ldquofar and wide to East Lothianrsquos beauty spots.Brian said the community resilience team were working hard to ensure the most vulnerable residents are receiving support and supplies during the lockdown, and the actions of daytrippers over the weekend had left them concerned.He said: ldquoUnfortunately, many peoplersquos worst fears were confirmed over the weekend with East Lothian being inundated with daytrippers driving down the coast from far and wide.ldquoDespite the very clear messages being given last week by the Scottish Government and East Lothian Council that the lsquorelaxed lockdown measuresrsquo still included only travellingessential, staying home as much as possible, not travelling more than five miles from your local area, avoiding tourist and beauty spots ndash the East Lothian coast road was rammed with cars all weekend and the beaches packed.As one local Panner put it to me: lsquoFolk are just going mental and not listening to what the governments are saying.rsquoldquoThe last thing we all need after more than two months of strict lockdown measures is a second wave of infections that puts huge pressure on the NHS and frontline health and social care services, as well as the resilience volunteers.ldquoThe Scottish Governmentrsquos lsquotesting and tracingrsquo strategy is now operational and people need to listen to the advicethey are asked to self-isolate."It is in their own interests and those of their family, friends and neighbours to stick to the rules.Last week was the busiest yet for the Pennypit Pantry, with , meals delivered over the course of the week.East Lothian Sunday Fresh Chicken Dinner Boxes, highlighted in last weekrsquos Courier, delivered  meals over the weekend.The community council also gave special thanks to Calum and Michelle Wilson who run The Goth pub and who have been providing breakfast packs to local families since the end of March.Brian said: ldquoThe Prestonpans resilience team are delighted to support this project as it is an additional resource providing lsquothe most important meal of the dayrsquo to local children.Contact detailsAny local businesses or anyone who wants to donate to any of the fantastic community-based projects can contact the resilience hotline telephone number   or email prestonpansresilience@gmail

title: community-resilience-volunteers-humbie-east-west-saltoun-macmerry-gladsmuir-ormiston-tranent-elphinstone
story: From collecting shopping and vital prescriptions to dog walking and simply being there for people, the volunteers are there for residents throughout the coronavirus crisis.Here, we look at five of the groups who are giving up their own time to help out.East Saltoun. Picture: Google MapsHumbie, East and West Saltoun and BoltonSERVICES remain on offer to people in need throughout a number of villages.Teams of volunteers have been set up in Humbie, East and West Saltoun, and Bolton to assist anyone with requests such as shopping or collecting prescriptions.Shena Jamieson, from Bolton, said those services remained in place for people needing assistance during the coronavirus pandemic.She planned to get in touch with volunteers to seeany issues had arisen in recent weeks.Contact detailsPeople in Bolton should contact Shena Jamieson on   or by email at shenajamieson@aol.East Saltoun residents can contact Buffy Neilson on   or buffyneilson@yahoo.In West Saltoun, Derek Smith is the point of contact on   or by emailing coruisk@gmail.In Humbie, people are encouraged to call Margo Hodge on   or email humbiehelp@gmailMacmerry. Picture: Google MapsMacmerry and GladsmuirIT IS BUSINESS as usual for the resilience team in Macmerry and Gladsmuir, and those who need help of any kind are encouraged to reach out and get in touch.Last month, the group started a pom pom initiative, which has been going from strength to strength over the weeks.It has seen both Macmerry and Gladsmuir decorated with pom poms hung by residents from places such as trees and fences using ribbons placed by resilience volunteers.The initiative has not only brightened up both villages but has also worked as a way to thank all key workers who continue to work amid the ongoing coronavirus pandemic.Stevie Sutherland, one of the co-ordinators, told the Courier that a banner was to be put up outside Macmerry Miners Club, also thanking key workers.The resilience teamrsquos hot meals service continues, and volunteers are still helping with shopping, prescription uplts and post office visits.Work on how community support can continue now restrictions have started to ease also continues, with efforts being made to ensure the system can pick up and run again without any issues.Contact detailsAnyone who needs assistance can find out more information at twitter MacmerryTeamOrmiston. Picture: Google MapsOrmistonRESIDENTS in Ormiston have been given a boost after the gala committee announced it will hold its annual Best Dressed House competition this month.Gala days across the county have been affected by the lockdown, with many, like Ormistonrsquos, cancelled.However, the committee is inviting people to enter their houses in the competition ahead of the socially distant judging, which is due to take place on June .Anyone can put forward their home and the deadline for taking part is June .The gala committee is also appealing for other ideas for activities that could be held within the current guidelines for social distancing.Friends of Ormiston Park have also reminded people that, while the easing of restrictions means people can meet in parks at a safe distance, childrenrsquos play areas remain closed.Contact detailsVolunteers are continuing to provide support and services to the most vulnerable residents and anyone in need can get in touch by contacting them on   between am and pm, seven days a week, or emailing Ormistonrcrteam@hotmailTranent. Picture: Google MapsTranent and ElphinstoneTHE resilience effort in Tranent continues to support local residents, and further appeals have been launched for volunteers and those who have been helping neighbours.Tranent and Elphinstone Community Council has been overseeing the local resilience effort, led by member Mike Falconer, the grouprsquos single point of contact .Mike has asked that residents who have been supporting their neighbours during the pandemic ndash for example, by helping with shopping ndash and who will soon be ing to work, potentially leaving neighbours without support, get in touch with him.People requesting the resilience teamrsquos help for neighbours have been asked to get their neighboursrsquo permission before calling.A second appeal has been put out for volunteers to support the grouprsquos food delivery service, which operates from St Martinrsquos Church Hall.Mike said: ldquoWe desperately need help from volunteers to direct the delivery driver volunteers coming in and out of the St Martinrsquos Church Hall car park Blair Halls food delivery base to the correct venue ndash especially when staff and some pupils start toto the school building.ldquoThis would involve being at St Martinrsquos Church Hall car park from approximately .am until about pm, Monday to Saturday ndash but not necessarily every day,you canrsquot manage.ldquoThe volunteers have delivered thousands of meals over the last few weeks and months but we need your help to keep it running smoothly.Contact detailsAnyone interested in either appeal is asked to contact Mike on tranentemergencyresponse@gmail or call  .

title: dvla-announces-important-changes-driving-licences-set-expire
story: The announcement, made yesterday, aims tohelp drivers to make necessary journeys without having to geta new photograph to renew their licence.Normally, drivers are required to renew their photocard licence every ten years, and bus and lorry drivers every five years.A new EU regulation has now been introduced which means photocards that expire betweenFebruary  andAugust ,  will be automatically extended for a further seven months from the date of expiry.Drivers will be sent a reminder to renew before their seven-month extension ends.This extension applies to the photocard. If a driverrsquos entitlement to drive is due to expire and they wish to continue to hold a valid licence, they will need to renew this entitlement in the normal way.What have the DVLA said DVLA Chief Executive Julie Lennard said:ldquoThis extension will make it easier for drivers who need to update their photocard licence with a new photograph."This means as long as they have a valid licence, drivers will be able to continue to make essential journeys.ldquoThe extension is automatic so drivers do not need to do anything and will be sent a reminder to renew their photocard before the extension ends.The DVLArsquos online services to renew your driving licence and replace a driving licence are available for those drivers who need to renew their entitlement to drive or replace a lost or stolen licence.

title: coronavirus-make-face-mask
story: First Minister Nicola Sturgeon confirmed this was under consideration in her daily briefing yesterday, but stressed there is no timescale on when the wearing of one mightenforced across the country.Ms Sturgeon was keen to emphasise medical face masks should be prioritised for frontline workers and instead has encouraged Scots to make their own face coverings from home."@context": "https:schema.org","@type": "VideoObject","name": "Sturgeon considering making face coverings mandatory in Scotland","description": "Nicola Sturgeon says she is considering making face coverings mandatory. The First Minister said the Government has not made a final decision whether to implement the policy.","thumbnailUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer v media AlflgpM poster.jpg width","uploadDate": "--T::+:","duration": "PDTHMS","contentUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer manests AlflgpM.mu","embedUrl": "https:www.eastlothiancourier video  ","publisher": "@type": "Organization","name": "East Lothian Courier","logo": "@type": "ImageObject","url": "https:www.eastlothiancourier sitelogo ","width": ,"height": Whether you are handy with a Singer or just want a quick fix, there are so many ways you can make sure you are protected.Heres our guide to dferent types and step-by-step instructions on how to make them.What do I need to make a face covering There are many dferent materials you can use to protect yourself and stop the spread of Covid- to those around you.This ranges from bandanas, to t-shirts, fabrics, to string. The important thing is you should be able to find most of these items in your home already.Think of this as a good chance to finally find a use for that t-shirt in the back of the cupboard youve been meaning to take to a charity shop for as long as you can remember.You dont need to be an expert in sewing machines to make your own face covering Well show you how to make some coverings in the next section, but here are some of the items you will need to make one:What are the dferent types of home-made face coverings and how can I make one The UK government advises washing your hands or using hand sanitiser before putting on and after taking off face coverings.You should also:The one with the bandanaOkay. Not many of us will have a spare bandana sitting around butyou do they are an easy way to make an effective covering.For this youll need: Elastic ties or hairpins, and your bandana. Thats it.Step one: Lay the cloth out flatStep two: Fold in halfStep three: Fold top third down, fold bottom up to meet itStep four: Thread through two elastic bandsStep five: Fold each side to the middle and tuck into the foldsThe one with the t-shirtHave a look in your cupboard. Wed bet you have at least one old t-shirt which either doesnt fit or looked more at home in a Wham video than .Well, now is the perfect time to say goodbye and recyle your old shirt for good.Heres what youll need: An old t-shirt, scissors, kitchen towel, pinsStep one: Draw pattern across arms and body of t-shirtStep two: Cut along patterns so you have two layers from front and back of t-shirtStep three: Pin one sideSteph four: Inset non-woven fabric material such as a paper towelStepfive: Pin other sideSteph six: Tie at back so it is tight across the nose and tight under the chinThe one that needs sewingThis is one for the wannabe sewing bees. Dust off that Singer and have a go and youll have an effective face covering in no time.Heres what youll need: A sewing machine, needle and thread, scissors, elastic, towel, fabricStep one: Cut two cloth rectangles cmxcmStep two: Place on top of each other, waysStep three: Fold over the top of the fabric .cm and stitch all the way acrossStep four: Fold the bottom up and stitch .cm inwards from the edge of either side - this will create a filter pocketStep five: Folder the shorter sides inwards about cm and stitch - leaving a gap to thread elasticStep six: Thread a cm piece of elastic through the hem on one side and tie the ends. Repeat on the other sideStep seven: Put kitchen paper inside as filterVisit here for more guidance from the UK Government.We have also used information from the Centre for Disease Control and Prevention .

title: column-easing-lockdown-restrictions-ruined-stupidity-others-says-msp
story: LAST weekend was the first of lsquophase onersquo of easing the lockdown, which now seems to have been with us forever.Many of us took the chance to see family face to face, albeit outside and at a distance, for the first time in many weeks.Others were able to enjoy golf, bowls or fishing at long last, eventhe clubhouse remained off limits.What a pity that some communities had any joy they might have felt in some easing of restrictions ruined by the stupidity of others who abused that progress.The countyrsquos coastal villages and other beauty spots were swamped with people heading for a day out and simply ignoring the advice not to travel more than five miles for leisure.Finding car parks and toilets closed, they parked, peed and worse without consideration, then left litter everywhere.The council has been caught between a rock and a hard place, instructed by the First Minister not to open car parks, andthey do facing accusations of encouraging the flouting of the rules. Yet chaos resulted.I know the council is discussing with government and COSLA how to respond. Police, traffic wardens and Countryside Rangers did their best but were overwhelmed.On Monday, the First Minister made clear thatthis continues we will go back into lockdown, and the guidance will be given the force of law but perhaps we should have done that first, and hopefully as we move into other phases the guidance will be better thought out, clearer and unambiguous.A further sign that we are not yet out of the woods was an inexplicable fall in numbers of Covid- tests.Further phases of leaving lockdown, such as school openings, depend on widespread community testing, and in parliament we continue to get no answers on why this is still not happening.There is still a real danger that the infection rate will rise again and more people will die unnecessarily.We all have a part to play. Please do follow the guidance to save lives.

title: primary-school-pupils-lead-whole-school-treasure-hunt-home
story: Primary  pupils organised and led a whole school virtual scavenger hunt for pupils and families.The P pupils organised a video conference call for each class in the school.The schoolrsquos senior pupils then worked in teams to host the challenges in the dferent video calls.A spokeswoman for the primary school said: ldquoP read out riddles and clues to the younger children and families, who then had to go and collect certain items around their house.ldquoThe pupils who were fastest to collect the items in each round andto their camera screen were allocated points.ldquoPoints were also allocated for lsquounusualrsquo items.ldquoFor example, one of the clues was lsquobring me something that is linked with the sea or oceanrsquo, and one pupil showed up with an entire fish tank!

title: musselburgh-marlins-become-first-east-lothian-club-achieve-top-swim-benchmark
story: Already proud holders of a SwiMark certicate, received in , they have now been awarded SwiMark Plus in Scottish Swimmingrsquos accreditation scheme which provides a nationally recognised standard for clubs and swim schools.Head coach Danny Kirkham said: ldquoMusselburgh Amateur Swimming Clubis delighted to have been awarded Scottish Swimmingrsquos highest accreditation, SwiMark Plus.ldquoThis means that Scottish Swimming recognises MASC as a quality programme which is swimmer centred and strives to ensure we provide the best environment possible for our swimmers to reach their full potential.ldquoThis award shows MASC are leading the way in setting new standards for swimming in the community. Through the work undertaken, a development plan which spans the whole club will ensure we keep progressing and moving forward to ensure MASC remains strong and sustainable long into the future.The club has come a long way since its origins in , when swimmers used to hone their skills in the local harbour. The pool at Loretto School was used over the years before the club moved to Musselburgh Sports Centre after it opened in .A year ago, MASCrsquos management committee and coaches held a planning meeting with Scottish Swimming to establish the steps required to be completed in order to achieve SwiMark Plus.A small voluntary project group embarked on reviewing, revising and signing off the extensive SwiMark criteria before engaging in consultative activities across the club, implementing revised and new policies and procedures, analysing data and producing a four year development and action plan.Club president and project manager Gill Downie said: ldquoMany thanks to the small project team heavily involved in delivering this huge feat through endless hours of blood, sweat and tears. It really is a remarkable achievement during the transitional year following chairman Jack Calderrsquos death ndash illustrating MASCrsquos resilience, drive and passion to be recognised as a trusted leader within aquatics sport by offering exceptional all-encompassing swimming development programmes, coaching education tuition and volunteer training within the community. In addition, effective club management and robust financial review systems will ensure MASC is a viable family-friendly resource within East Lothian well into the future.Alan Reed, Scottish Swimmingrsquos regional swimming development manger , added: ldquoWith the committee and other members working hard to gain this award, they have shown that they are a really strong and sustainable club.ldquoA crucial part of the accreditation is the formation of a development plan ndash this ensures that the club is making consistent progress and looks towards the future.ldquoThe club has excellent structures that have been put in place through the process and this has been demonstrated by all the engagement and activity the club has continued through this recent period of change. It has been a pleasure working with the club and helping support them to gain their SwiMark Plus accreditation.The top benchmark is also held by East Lothian Swim Team which provides a performance training environment for countyrsquos top talent. The best swimmers from Musselburgh, Tranent and Haddington Amateur Swimming Clubs train together as a single composite team to achieve success at East District, Scottish National, British and International levels.

title: tim-tales-kings-elephant
story: This week is a story from India which I like, not least because the main character is my favourite animal an elephant.Irsquove loved elephants since early childhood. They are a giant of nature, yet also incredibly intelligent. They feel emotion like we do, in fact possibly more so as the emotional part of their brain is even more developed than that of humans.The old saying that ldquoan elephant never forgets is rooted in this fact. An elephantrsquos emotional intelligence comes from its ability to remember and recall distant memory. Like humans, an elephantrsquos way of being is mostly learned in early le, rather than just based on instinct.They are therefore highly sensitive creatures, influenced and affected by what they experience just as we are.Irsquove heard dferent versions of this tale, and here I have peppered it very slightly with my own style:Once, a king in ancient India owned an elephant. This royal elephant was the joy not just of the king, but also his people.The trainer would ride the elephant every day along the streets. She was a magnicent sight, and children would run out to wave and watch the elephant go by. The trainer took a dferent route each day so people in dferent neighbourhoods all had a chance to enjoy the spectacle.The people felt a real love and affinity for the elephant. Despite her size and strength, she was gentle and affectionate with the people. She would pat children carefully on their heads with her trunk and took care in where she walked.The elephant made people feel safe. More than once she had saved a child from drowning in the nearby river, or from a predator from the jungle. She was a sacred animal to the people.But then people began to notice a change in the elephantrsquos behaviour. She became aggressive and unpredictable. Instead of being patient with the children she knocked them out of her way with her trunk. Instead of being careful where she walked, she deliberately trampled on peoplersquos gardens.The trainer tried his best to control the elephant, but she seemed like a dferent animal. He couldnrsquot understand why she was behaving so dferently.It just got worse, until one day the elephant suddenly set off on a charge and rampaged through the streets, trumpeting loudly as she charged at the terried people, almost killing some of them.The king was horried and ordered the elephant to be confined to her stables. With dficulty she was finally brought under control and locked in.ldquoWhat is going on  asked the king to the trainer.ldquoI have no idea your majesty he replied, ldquoitrsquos asshe is a dferent elephant.ldquoPerhaps the elephant is ill in some way  suggested one of the kingrsquos advisors. But the vet found nothing physically wrong.Then the trainer suggested asking an old man who lived in the jungle as ldquohe is known for his wisdom in understanding animals, perhaps he will know what the cause of this is.So the king sent a messenger and the old man came to the royal palace.ldquoCan you help  asked the king.The old man asked to be left alone with the elephant for a while.When he ed he looked at the king and said: ldquoWhatever is wrong is something that cannot be seen. I must spend some time with the elephant to understand what is troubling her.And so the old man decided to watch over the elephant that night. He smeared himself in mud to mask his scent and hid in a corner of the stable.It was late evening when he heard voices.A group of men had entered the stables from a small side door. They were a gang of murderers. They were using the royal elephant stable as a place to meet and plan their activities. And in so doing they recounted stories of their deeds.Their leader was a man with a cold and ruthless heart. He told stories about his le and deeds, of how hersquod murdered and tortured people he didnrsquot like. Members of his gang laughed and shared their tales too, likewise full of hatred and cruelty.The elephant slumbered as these tales were told, but they were unknowingly heard by her. When the elephant woke the following morning, the tales of hate and violence still swirled in her mind.The old man went to the king.ldquoYour majesty, there are two things you must do to cure the elephant.ldquoThe first is to remove the murderers who meet in the stables at night. The second is you must find the kindest people, who live their lives with love and understanding. Then ask them to meet at night in the stable as the elephant sleeps and tell each other stories from their lives tales of love and understanding. If you do this, then the elephant will be cured.The king looked bemused.ldquoI will most certainly remove the murderers, he said, ldquobut are you saying that stories will cure the elephant ldquoYes, your majesty, replied the old man, ldquobut the right stories. You see we are made from the stories we hear.He went on: ldquoIf we constantly hear tales of hatred and violence then those stories paint our vision of le with fear, loathing and cruelty.ldquoButwe mostly hear tales of love and understanding, then our mind is coloured with kindness for others, and for ourselves.ldquoWe are affected by the stories we hear, evenwe donrsquot realise we have been listening to them.ldquoYour elephant was unknowingly listening to tales of hatred and killing every night as she slept. So her mind was filled with hate and distrust her vision of the world changed and so did her behaviour.ldquoIf she hears good stories then she will eventually become her kind self again.The king nodded in understanding and agreed to act on this. Within a few weeks the elephantrsquos behaviour had changed for the better.ldquoYou are indeed wise in the ways of elephants, the king said to the old man.ldquoThe truth in this is not just for elephants, the old man replied.ldquoPeople are like your elephant the stories they hear will paint their world and affect how they live in it.The king nodded once again.ldquoMy job is done, said the old man, ldquoI will nowto the forest.ldquoBy the way, your elephant will have a calf, and her calf must hear good stories too.ldquoHow can I pay you for your wisdom  asked the king.The old man thought for a moment, then said: ldquoBe a king who tells good stories tales of kindness and understanding. And be a good listener to the stories told by your people.ldquoThen you will be a truly great leader and your kingdom will flourish and be a happier place.ldquoIf you do that, it will be my greatest reward.

title: strawberry-moon-2020-time-see-skies-uk
story: The Strawberry Moon coincideswith summer solstice once every  years when the moon is situated on the opposite side of the Earth as the Sun - whichfully illuminates its round shape.Unfortunately, despite its fruity name, the moon may notappear in warm colours as we would expect.The lunar event got its name fromNative American tribes, who used the moon to help them indicate when fruit would be ripened.What does NASA say about the Strawberry Moon As described by NASA: ldquoThe Maine Farmers Almanac first published Indian names for the full moons in the s.ldquoAccording to this almanac, the full moon in June or the last full Moon of spring is known as the Strawberry Moon, a name universal to just about every Algonquin tribe.ldquoThe name comes from the relatively short season for harvesting strawberries in northeastern North America.The Strawberry Moon has also been referred to as the Hot Moon.So, when can I see it You can expect to see the spectacular lunar event at about .pm BST tonight .According to the Royal Greenwich Observatory in London, the Strawberry Moon will last for up to three orfour days.

title: black-lives-matter-donate-help-get-diverse-books-primary-schools
story: The fund -which has raised over pound, since it was created on Wednesday, June  - aims to help black, Asian and minority ethnicstudents to feel represented by their school libraries.The initiative was inspired by protests that have taken place across the world calling for justice after the death of George Floyd, who died in police custody in Minneapolis on May .Who created the fund Scott Emmons, who created the fund, told the PA news agency:ldquoTherersquos a lack of books in primary schools where not only can teachers teach the white students about these issues, but also the BAME students are severely under-represented in the books that they have."Mr Emmons, , who lives in Wanstead, added: ldquoI went to the protest on Wednesday in Hyde Park and came away feeling so energised. There were so many people in Hyde Park who caredhellip there are so many people wanting to change, wanting to help.What books will the fund help The fund will put bundles into libraries, which include  books for children aged three to , and include the stories of Nelson Mandela and Rosa Parks.In , a report from the Centre for Literacy in Primary Education revealed that over the course of the year, only  per centof childrenrsquos books published in the UK had a BAME hero.These books allow those dficult conversations to startldquoIf therersquos no literature there to start this conversation, and white teachers find it dficult to speak about, then these are the tools that allow you to have that conversation, Mr Emmons told PA.Mr Emmons explained that he would like the initiative to go further than the GoFundMe page he has created, with the hope of schools tailoring the books to fit their own schoolsrsquo needs.He said: ldquoThe idea for this campaign is not to pay for everyonersquos books, itrsquos to be that driving force and that spark to put pressure on schools to get these books in and allow the children in their classrooms to see themselves represented.ldquoIt isnrsquot just a case of a lack of fundinghellip a lot of the schools do have the funding theyrsquore just not prioritising correctly. Theyrsquore not purchasing the right books.How can I make a donation To see the pagersquos donations, visit: http:gofundme f help-our-children-read-about-race

title: tell-difference-symptoms-hay-fever-covid-19
story: It comes as the weather gets warmer and summer approaches, with hay fever sufferers having to cope with more pollen in the air.But could coughing be a sign of hayfever, and as coronavirus sticks around, how can you tell it apart from allergy symptoms Heres what you need to know.What is hay fever Hay fever, also known as seasonal allergies, tends to flare up between late March and September according to the NHS, as this is when itrsquos warm, humid, windy and when pollen count is at its highest.Healthline says: ldquoWhen your body is exposed to allergens, it releases histamines.ldquoHistamines are meant to protect you from harm, but they can also cause the allergy symptoms that make some seasons uncomfortable.Hay fever and its symptoms are not contagious for those around you.Is coughing a symptom of hay fever Hay fever comes with a lot of dferent symptoms, one of which is a cough.Other symptoms include:The NHS says thatyou also suffer from asthma, you might also experience:How do I tell the dference between hay fever and coronavirus With hay fever and coronavirus having overlapping symptoms, like coughing, loss of smell and headaches, some people might get confused about what their symptoms mean.Most hay fever sufferers are affected from childhood, and will probably be expecting their symptoms every year around the same time.If yoursquove never had hay fever before, and you suddenly begin experiencing symptoms, itrsquos understandable that this might cause concern.Patient Info says: ldquoAround one in five people with hay fever get symptoms for the first time over the age of , so therersquos no reason to assume an adultrsquos symptoms canrsquot be caused by hayfever just because theyrsquove never had it before.Marc Donovan, chief pharmacist at Boots, says: ldquoHay fever doesnrsquot cause a high temperature and most people donrsquot feel unwell.The NHS explains that the two main symptoms of Covid- are a high temperature and a new, continuous cough.A high temperature means that you feel hot to touch on your chest or back - you do not need to measure your temperature.A new, continuous cough is also defined as ldquocoughing a lot for more than an hour, or three or more coughing episodes in  hours.Boots Pharmacy released an graphic which shows the dference between hay fever symptoms and coronavirus symptoms, and included information like:How do I treat hay fever There is currently no cure for hayfever, but there are things you can do to help your symptoms according to the NHS, which includes:A pharmacy can also help with hay fever as they can provide you with things like antihistamine tablets or nasal sprays to help with your symptoms.

title: glasgow-set-enter-lockdown-phase-2-next-week---changes
story: The First Minister saidthat, "at least in part", more of the coronavirus lockdown measures will be eased on at the next formal review on June .At the Scottish Governmentdaily briefing, Ms Sturgeonsaid: "I am optimistic that, ten days from now at the next formal review, we will be able to move, at least in part, into the next phase of our routemap out of lockdownwith more inidual freedoms restored and more businesses able to open up and operate again."But that depends on each and every one of us, so please, please, stick with it for now."It comes as figures shows for a second day in a row there were no new deaths reported overnight in Scotland.This comes with the message of caution, with fewer deaths usuallyrecorded over the weekends.Nicola Sturgeon optimistic of entering Phase  next weekWhile not all of these may take place, these are some of the measures set out in the routemap out of lockdown for Phase .Seeing friends and familyFrom June , people in Scotland may be able to meet people from other households indoors for the first time - while maintaing physical distancing and hygeine measures.You will also be able to meet with larger groups including family and friends outside.Shopping and pubsFrom Phase , the Scottish Government says pubs and restaurants CAN open outdoor spaces such as beer gardens - so long as social distancing measures can be maintained.Outdoor markets can also reopen, provided there can be controls on the number of people within the market and distancing is kept.Previously closed small retail units can also reopen - again with the underlying pin of physical distancing.SportsThe resumption of professional sport, in line with public health advice, is currently planned for Phase .Likewise,sports courts and playgrounds may also be able toreopen from this date.However gyms will not be able to reopen until Phase .Weddings and worshipIt is hoped that under Phase , marriages and civil partnerships can take place in Scotland with minimal number of attendees.The routemap also says places of worship will be able to reopen for private prayer - but not for extended groups until Phase .TransportPeople may be able to drive locally for leisure under the Phase  routemap.Public transport can increase their capacity but will remain signicantly limited to allow for physical distancing.WorkingWorking from home remains the default position.But the guidance says non-essential indoor, non-office based workplaces can reopen - title: mcdonalds-glasgow-set-open-walk-ins-month---
story: Following a closed test in London last month,  service station locations on UK motorways will open for takeaway from Wednesday, June .Then, from June  onwards, they will gradually roll-out to high streets, towns and city centres.The fast-food chain also plan a trialled relaunch of the McDonaldrsquos breakfast service from that date.McDonaldrsquos UK  Ireland CEO Paul Pomroy said: ldquoWersquore delighted to be back.ldquoI am extremely proud of our employees, franchisees and suppliers who are working so hard in so many communities already.ldquoThe high street is at the heart of our business, it is where we started in the UK, in Woolwich over  years ago.ldquoIn line with Government changes to lockdown restrictions, over the next few weeks and months wersquoll reopen on high streets across the UK and in towns and cities in Ireland.ldquoI know that opening those doors will be incredibly satisfying for our restaurant teams, but it will also mean them getting used to the measures we have implemented to enable us to safely .ldquoSo please continue to support them and follow the social distancing measures wersquove introduced for the safety of our teams and you.What do McDonaldrsquos say about new safety measures -We will provide clear signposting and floor-markings to create a one-way system around our restaurants for you and our delivery partner couriers-We will only allow certain numbers of people inside our restaurants at a time to help you and us adhere to social distancing ndash this will y depending upon the restaurant size and lay-out-When you visit us for takeaway, we will welcome you inside when a space becomes available, and wersquoll ask you to sanitise your hands at the cleaning stations we are introducing in all restaurants-We will have fewer self-order screens switched on and will sanitise those in use at least every  minutes. You can also order via the My McDonaldrsquos app-If you can visit alone to collect your food, please do so, however we know this isnrsquot always possible ndash children are of course still welcome, but for now wersquoll be putting away our crayons and colouring sheets and keeping the play areas and digital play areas closed-Our seating areas, customer toilets and lts will remain closed-As our dining areas will not be open, our recycling points will also remain closed but most of our packaging can be recycled so please do dispose of it responsibly and recycle wherever possible when you get home-To help protect our employees and other customers, we ask you not to visityou feel unwell.

story: Here we look at some of the businesses who will no longer be operating in the city and the ones under threat.Remnant KingsCity location: Howard StreetA total of  stafflost their jobs from the firmrsquos bases in Glasgow, Hamilton, and Edinburgh after the administrators were called in.The firm, which started in Glasgow in , said that although they were historically profitable, they have since suffered from declining turnover and trading dficulties in recent years caused by changing consumer habits.:Glasgow firm Remnant Kings goes into admistration resulting in job lossesOasis and Warehouse GroupCity locations past and present: Buchanan Galleries, Silverburn, Princes Square, and Glasgow Fort.The company behind Oasis and Warehouse went into administration in April when Deloitte was appointed as administrator.All stores haveclosed indefinitely whileonline sales have stopped.Reports say the fashion brands have been sold to restructuring business Hilco in a deal which includes stock but not the  stores or  concessions.Hash Ladha, chief executive of Oasis Warehouse, previouslysaid: ldquoThis is a situation that none of us could have predicted a month ago, and comes as shocking and dficult news for all of us.ldquoWe as a management team have done everything we can to try and save the iconic brands that we love.:Oasis and Warehouse who have shops in Glasgow fall into administrationCath KidstonCity location: Gordon StreetCath Kidston said they will not reopen their shops when lockdown ends.They called in the administrators in April with the closure of shops costing around  jobs.It is understood that the owner of the retro fashion brand has secured a deal to buy back the brand and its online operation. title: five-alternative-fathers-day-experiences-lockdown
story: A day trip, family get together, a meal at dads favourite might have been on the cards to celebrate Fathers Day, but with our choices restricted this year due to lockdown there are some great alternatives out there.Your dad might be just as happy, or long for, playing a solitary round of golf at his local course or sitting by the riverbank waiting for his catch of the day, but might also want to come together with loved ones to celebrate his special day.From small garden gatherings, to Zoom parties, or virtual museum tours or a local stroll, we bring you the best ideas to make it a Fathers Day to remember.Virtual Museum TourWhile all their museums remain closed due to coronavirus, the National Museum of Scotland have opened their virtual doors for people to enter a world of discovery.Their website gives you the chance to explore their collections and discover more about amazing objects through stories, films, games and resources.There is the chance to delve into our animated adventures and find out more about le in ancient Egypt, learn some Mandarin. Watch videos on a day in the le of an ancient Egyptian priestPriests occupied a unique place in ancient Egyptian society. Find out what they did every day and why in this short animated film. Created for the Discovering Ancient Egypt gallery.There is also the chance to The East Asian CalendarThe East Asian calendar uses a unique system to measure and mark the passing of time. Discover the twelve animals in the calendar and find out what your animal sign is. Created for the East Asia gallery.For more information go to www.nms.ac.uk national-museum-of-scotland If you fancy going a little further afield in your virtual discovery why not take a look at the Louvre in Paris.Activities on offer at the online Louvre include:- One minute in a museum- YouTubers at the Louvre- Mona Lisa VR experience-  years of history- A closer look at Louvre artworksOr you can take a virtual tour of Founding Myths: From Hercules to Darth Vader.The Louvrersquos Petite Galerie first exhibition tells how illustrators, sculptors, painters, puppeteers, filmmakers, and musicians around the world have drawn inspiration from myths, given them form, and brought them to le.Local family walkNow we are allowed to exercise more than once a day and can meet up with another household, a walk near your home could be the ideal gathering.Check out the Ramblers Scotland website to find walks close to home of dfering levels. A great way to enjoy daily local exercise is to try one of their  free mapped Medal Routes short, circular walks in every local authority area in Scotland.Medal Routes are downloadable maps for short, fun circular walks of ,  or  minutes. They are available in every local authority area across Scotland and there are over  walking routes to choose from.The organisation has been working hard to help inspire people to keep active during lockdown - including via through their #RoamSweetHome campaign.If you are giving the Medal Routes a go in your local area during your daily exercise, they are looking for you to share photos or videos from your Medal Route walk by using the #RoamSweetHome hashtag or tagging us on social media.For more information got to www.ramblers.org.uk scotland.aspxGo for a bike rideSales of bikes have soared during lockdown with many shops now having waiting lists after being completely sold out. Transport Secretary Michael Matheson recently confirmed cycling levels are % higher compared with the lockdown baseline, while Cycling Scotlandrsquos automatic cycling counters at  spots around the country revealed remarkable results, with one in Dunfermline recording an increase of % since lockdown.There are a number of family routes to explore without going too far from home. National Cycle Network routes in Scotland run through many areas of outstanding natural beauty, taking in vast forests, iconic castles, shimmering lochs, tranquil glens and spectacular coastlines. The routes provide a unique snapshot of the countryrsquos rich history whilst also connecting all of Scotlands major cities.There are approximately , milesof National Cycle Network routes in Scotland, including  miles of traffic-free routes which use a mix of railway path, canal towpath, forest road, shared-use path, segregated cycle lanes and redetermined rural footways.More information can be found at www.sustrans.org.ukVirtual park discoveryWhile travelling too far afield might just be a distant dream at the moment, we will have to make do with exploring some parts of the great outdoors from our armchairs.Prepare to feel slightly dizzy on the virtual tour for Calornias Yosemite National Park. Virtual Yosemite is a groundbreaking interactive tour of one of Americarsquos most popular and spectacular natural environments. The project is unique in both the depth of its coverage and the quality of its imagery.It was created and photographed by pioneering virtual realityphotographer Scott Highton, who has specialized in VR photography since the early s.Virtual Yosemite allows online visitors to experience over  dferent locations within Yosemite and its surrounding areas, in all seasons. Over  percent of the locations covered are accessible to Yosemite visitors via roads or trails. The deg interactive panoramas are all presented in high resolution, so viewers can zoom in and out to see details, and can pan fully around, including looking upward and downward. Dizzying views from the tops of Yosemitersquos famous clfs and waterfalls are available, along with peaceful locations along trails and in well-known parts of Yosemite Valley.For more information go to www.virtualyosemite.org Closer to home enjoy an aerial view of Loch Lomond National Park under #Lochdown. See the beauty of nature during the coronavirus lochdown through a series of videos which have been posted on their website. Take in the enchanting Loch Achray, a small freshwater loch in the heart of the Trossachs.For more information go to https:www.lochlomond-trossachs.org park-authority lochdown aerial-tours-of-the-national-park Watch a dads favourite movieYou can now watch some streaming services together evenyou are not in the same household and it could be the answer to having a family movie night while social distancing or apart from dad this Fathers Day.Netflix is one example where you can watch the same film together. Netflix Party is a Google Chrome-exclusive extension that only requires one person to install it, making it easy to set up.Once you install it, choose a movie or show, pause it, and then click the red ldquoNP button at the top right of your browser to get a link to a shared session. The extension allows you to chat with everyone in the viewing session, but doesnrsquot allow you to put in a name, so yoursquoll have to remember your friendsrsquo random symbols.Netflix Party allows for full-screen viewing and anybody in the session can hit pause, play or scrub through the timeline.

title: letters-tories-snp-held-equally-culpable
story: The Scottish NHS is fully devolved. The First Minister has taken control of the management of the pandemic in Scotland. She has stated on many occasions that she takes the decisions and the responsibility and she has fronted every daily press conference, a feat of stamina and leadership that is admirable in itself. Butthe ldquoelite has failed, so has the First Minister.Its not aswe were not warned. There were at least four reports, three specically for the Scottish Government, that told of lack or equipment and processes to handle a pandemic, but it appears that the warnings were ignored, and the necessary preparations were never made. It is also obvious that the UK did not lock down quickly enough, but the first signicant outbreak was in Edinburgh and it was covered up by the First Minister. Had it been known to the public, pressure for an earlier lockdown would have been likely. Instead concerts and sporting events were allowed to continue, including the Scotland-France rugby on March . The Old Firm game of March  was cancelled by the SPFL, not the Scottish Government. BBC Scotlands Disclosure programme calculated that a two-week delay could have cost , Scottish lives over the following month.The lack of preparedness and delayed lockdown affected the UK and the devolved administrations in equal measure, resulting in lack of PPE, hospital beds, ventilators and other necessary equipment. The urging of the WHO to ldquotest, test, test was ignored in Scotland as much as England, and current testing levels are lower in Scotland. Infections are at the same rate in Scotland. The death rate from the virus is the same. Excess deaths are the same. Deaths in care homes are slightly worseanything. Discharging potentially infected people, and therefore the virus, from hospitals into care homes is the same. There is the same callousness in refusing to move the elderly sick from care homes to hospital. The result in all of the UK has been more infections and extra deaths.A good comparator of success or failure is New Zealand, with the same population as Scotland but with  deaths compared to our ,. It is dficult to see how such breath-taking levels of incompetence bolster any case for ldquoindependence except with those obsessed with it in the first place. Andthe failure of an ldquoelite is the cause, as Mr McKenna suggests, then the Tory elite in Westminster and the SNP elite in Holyrood would seem to be more or less equally culpable.Alex Gallagher, Labour Councillor, North Ayrshire Council, Largs.READING Kevin McKennas column on Saturday made me wonder: able writer for your paper that he is, does he ever read your paper Your front-page lead story in the very same editionhad already demolished his assertions. Tom Gordonrsquos compelling exposures showed that the Scottish Governmentrsquos suppression of information Scottish people are entitled to know, as well as the damaging untruths we had been fed, are a cause for great concern.The fact that an incompetent elite in charge of the Covid- virus in London is leading to lack of trust, hardly confirms that similar ldquoelites are not mishandling the crisis where.Your revelation that the Scottish Government shared the Iris Report in February  with the UK Governmentshowed that both Tory and SNP Governments are jointly culpable of a disastrous lack of preparations for a pandemic that was predictable and predicted. You rightly report the view that ldquoalarm bells were ringing for both the Scottish and UK governments. Surely objective readers have concluded that both administrations failed catastrophically, resulting in a huge number of lives being lost.Elsewhere in the same edition the impact on Scottish education was exposed in David Bolrsquos coruscating article headed ldquoPupils have been left severely traumatised". Again an indication that Nicola Sturgeonrsquos handling of these matters is no better than Boris Johnsonrsquos.Moreover, Saturdayrsquos Herald was not a one-off. Switching scores of frail elderly patients from hospitals into care homes, without their or their familiesrsquo agreement, is surely beyond defending far less a case for independence.The consequences of the Nike Conference in Edinburgh and the cover-up which followed will not go away.Boris Johnsonrsquos appalling handling of the Dominic Cummings affair remains without justication. But anyone who followed Ms Sturgeonrsquos attempts, for a whole day, to seek to retain her hapless adviser, until her own career was clearly in jeopardy, will hardly be convinced that the First Ministerrsquos motivation was at all laudable.Mr McKennarsquos repeated description of the many who disagree with separatism as ldquoUnionists is offensive to those who understand its connotations. The clear majority of Scots ndash amounting to an almost  per cent majority ndash to reject the ldquoonce in a letime choice should not have their views distorted. We choose to love our country, Scotland, and to work with others in the United Kingdom to achieve a better society and continue to hold to account an ldquoelite ldquowhether it exists in Holyrood or Westminster.Lest I am thought to be over-critical of Kevin McKenna, I welcomed his recollection that a Labour leader, Clement Attlee saved Britain, including Scotland, from the horrors of fascism by rejecting Lord Halax. I imagine Sir Starmer would agree wholly with that,not the rest of the article.Tom Clarke, Coatbridge.TOM Gordonrsquos exposeacute lays bare the damage being done to the relationship between the people of Scotland and those who govern us.His revelation that almost , patients have acquired Covid- and more than  have died after being admitted to hospital for other conditions is deplorable. But the attempt by Jeane Freeman, the Health Secretary, to appear to camouflage this and to speak instead of  ldquoincidents of Covid- on other wards is despicable.AC Grayling has previously written that ldquoin the related arts of politics and government, judicious economies with truth are a stock in trade, and the learned philosopher may well be right, but onlywe let them get away with it.When dealing with the impact of this pandemic, we need our leaders to tell us in plain language exactly how it is, no matter how bad. If they do not, and others have to speak truth to power, then our government has failed us.Bob Scott, Drymen.AN active No campaigner in  I now find myself unable to bear the thought of being subjected to a future of relentless mis-governance by such second-rate politicians as make up the current Westminster Cabinet.On the other hand, my principal concern about independence has always been the impact of the inevitable financial turmoil on those in poverty and otherwise deprived and powerless after a decade of Conservative austerity. The Yes SNP Green coalition has been unwilling to acknowledge, far less address, that issue.And so I believe that the Government and people of Scotland must find a way of addressing the issue of how we can deal with the consequences of being part of the Dystopian DysUnited Kingdomwith its architectsrsquo rejection of the UK values its citizens once believed were at least implied in its unwritten constitution.I find myself thinking that a resounding vote for an SNP Green alliance next year with a correspondingly overwhelming rejection of Jackson Carlawrsquos Conservatives would be the only way to put the necessary shot over the bows of the DDUK. A risky strategy for a non-nationalist  Probably, but presently I see no alternative when faced with a Government determined to create an ldquoindependent England founded on closer ties with a Trumpian United States.John Milne, Uddingston.THE political consequences of Brexit have so far been more rapid and lethal than its economic damage, leaving Britain with a Gilbert-and-Sullivan style leadership of spectacular incompetence during one of the worst public health crises in recent history.Out of , excess deaths, , could have been avoided had we acted like any other European and East Asian nation. On a single day last week,  people died from coronavirus in the UK ndash more than in all  EU countries over the same  hours.North and south of the Border, as government failures multiply, the default position is evasion and denial. In the past it didnt really matter who was nominally running the country as we had one of the worldrsquos most effective administrative machine.Today a weak, politicised civil service outsources to incompetent companies while co-ordinating existing organisations, such as NHS laboratories or local public health departments, is far beyond an organisation which is afraid to speak truth to power.Rev Dr John Cameron, St Andrews.AM I the only one noticing the disparities between how the UK Government deals with the EU trade deal talks compared to those with the US There seems to be no real will to engage with the EU: accusations of truculence and blocking deals are branded on both sides. Time is running out, yet there seems no political will on the side of the UK to extend the talks despite the Covid crisis.On the other hand, trade talks with the US are going swimmingly: the firm promise of Boris Johnson not to open the UK market to chlorinated chicken has already been broken hormone-fed beef will no doubt follow. All the rules, regulations and in particular: protections that our membership of the EU brought with it will be broken, one by one. I have no doubt that the opening-up of the NHS will come about as well. Did the UK vote for those sunny uplands  Scotland didnrsquot.Trudy Duffy-Wigman, Crook of Devon.Read more: Letters: Scottish Government must take responsibility for what has gone wrong

title: opinion-daren-fitzhenry-uncertain-times-freedom-information-important-ever
story: As Scottish Information Commissioner, I am responsible for promoting and enforcing Scotlandrsquos freedom of informationlaw. So both in my role as Commissioner and as a member of the public, Irsquove been considering how public authorities have adapted their approach to sharing information of all kinds since the impact of this pandemic began to be felt ndash and how they will do so in weeks and months ahead.Inevitably we all have questions about the decisions being made by our leaders and public services, and never more so than at a time when those decisions, sadly, may mean the dference between le and death. This is why it is so vital that Scotlandrsquos law ensures everyone has a right to seek information from public authorities, and ndash with only very few, limited exceptions ndash to receive it.For some public authorities, changes brought about by the current disruptions will make this challenging . However, not all will be impacted by the pandemic in the same way, and every authority must continue to respond to FOI requests promptly, and in any event within the  working day timeline.The Scottish Parliament has, however, acknowledged the challenges faced by authorities and has accepted that sometimes, even when responding promptly, it will not be possible to meet this timeline. The current emergency legislation therefore allows me, in certain circumstances relating to the pandemic, to decide that an authority has not breached the law evenit has failed to respond to a request within  working days. I have issued detailed guidance on the emergency changes to FOI law on my website, and will continue to enforce these provisions firmly and fairly.Crucially, FOI law also places a duty on public authorities to publish information about the work they do, the decisions they take and the services they provide ndash in a proactive way and not just when requested. This duty remains unchanged but is more important now than ever.Since we are all coming to accept that the disruption caused by the pandemic will continue for some time, I hope and expect that public authorities in Scotland will respond by adapting their ways of working, learning from this challenge, and updating their practices to ensure that people can easily access the information that matters to them ndash during this dficult time and beyond.By publishing key information proactively, clearly and speedily, authorities can both reduce the time they spend responding to requests for information later, and promote the transparent culture we all want and expect in our public services.The importance of this point was clearly highlighted by MSPs in the Scottish Parliamentrsquos Public Audit and Post-Legislative Scrutiny Committee last month, in their report on the current state of FOI law. Although the Committeersquos report was agreed before the outbreak of Covid- in Scotland, many of their recommendations highlight the real opportunities we have not only to maintain, but to improve, access to information for people in Scotland, and I look forward to helping them become a reality.Ultimately, we ndash citizens, public authorities and regulators ndash are in this together. In the face of all the disruption and uncertainty we are living through, we have a chance to change the way we understand and interact with one another about key decisions and services for the better. I hope and believe that with some determination, hard work and open dialogue, we can make a real dference.Daren Fitzhenry is Scottish Information Commissioner. He is the independent public official responsible for promoting and enforcing Scotlandrsquos freedom of information law, appointed by Her Majesty the Queen, on the nomination of the Scottish Parliament.Full information about freedom of information law and rights in Scotland is available on the Commissionerrsquos website at www.itspublicknowledge.info.Detail about freedom of information during the coronavirus pandemicis set out in the Commissionerrsquos Covid- and FOI information hub at www.itspublicknowledge.info covid.All columnists are free to express their opinions. They donrsquot necessarily represent the view of The Herald.

title: frustrated-msps-demand-scottish-government-files-alex-salmond-inquiry
story: The Holyrood inquiry into the Governmentrsquos mishandling of the  in-house investigation made its anger plain after officials appeared to hide behind the Covid crisis.It has now set a firm timetable for the Government to hand over ldquoemails, minutes, notes, texts, papers and WhatsApp messages in the coming weeks, ahead of public evidence sessions in the autumn.:MSP calls for greater ersity in politics as Scots elect just five BAME people to parliamentIt follows increasingly frosty correspondence between committee convener Linda Fabiani and the Scottish Governmentrsquos top official, permanent secretary Leslie Evans.Released by the Scottish Parliament tonight, the emails show the committee asking for information in April and May, but Ms Evans failing to commit to firm dates for handing it over despite the Government already identying and preserving material.Last month Ms Evans said key people were ldquocurrently playing a central role in the Scottish Governmentrsquos Covid- response, a problem complicated by remote working.Ms Fabiani last week wrote a withering reply expressing ldquoserious concerns about Ms Evansrsquos proposed, drawn-out timetable.Ms Fabiani said: ldquoWe recognise that the Scottish Governmentrsquos current focus is on the Covid- response but the lack of progress to date in receiving any information is the source of much frustration and concern amongst Members across all parties.ldquoIt is also impinging on the Committeersquos ability to interrogate what it knows will be a large quantity of information ahead of the forthcoming oral evidence sessions.ldquoI therefore expect the necessary steps to be put in place to move this process along in order to provide this information in time for our deadline of the end of July.ldquoOr,that is not possible, I would welcome a clear explanation of why that is the case.The committee was mothballed last year after Mr Salmond was charged with sexual assaults relating to his time in office, but restarted after his acquittal on all  counts in March.Its focus is the Governmentrsquos probe into two complaints of sexual misconduct made against Mr Salmond in  by two female civil servants.:Coronavirus: Sturgeon rips into Tories for putting politics before the pandemicThe former First Minister later won a judicial review at the Court of Session in January  after the Government admitted the probe, overseen by Ms Evans, was unfair, unlawful and ldquotainted by apparent bias because the investigating officer had been in prior contact with the complainants, landing taxpayers with a pound, bill for Mr Salmondrsquos legal costs.Nicola Sturgeon then admitted staying in contact with Mr Salmond while he was being investigated by her officials.The MSPs will examine how the Government probe was bungled, as well Ms Sturgeonrsquos conduct.A separate investigation into whether Ms Sturgeon broke the ministerial code has also been restarted since Mr Salmondrsquos trial.

title: opinion-andrew-mckie-cant-hong-kong-firth-clyde
story: Even so, I fancy I cut a more dignied figure than Tony Blair did that night, since he was handing over  per cent of the population of British Dependent Territories ndash about . million people ndash to a despotic regime notoriously indferent to human rights and officially founded on Leninism, as modied by Mao and Chinarsquos then leader, Deng Xiaoping, whose catchy maxim was ldquoPractice is the sole criterion for the truth.Well,yoursquore entirely pragmatic, or cynical, you might take that as no more than a statement of the obvious in politics. And to be fair to Mr Blair, who had only just become Prime Minister, the terms of the settlement were largely set by the negotiations during Margaret Thatcherrsquos time in government which were initially led by Sir Edward Heath, with his stellar record of undermining UK interests. Standing up to China, admittedly, wasnrsquot an easy task then ndash when Deng told Mrs Thatcher he could ldquotake the whole lot in an afternoon she admitted there wasnrsquot anything she could do to stop it ndash and it may be even harder now.Fat Pangdid try to do something to safeguard the interests of the citizens of Hong Kong by expanding the democratic franchise but, as is now apparent, you canrsquot really do a great deal to protect human rights when the incoming government is a dictatorship.So the current Governmentrsquos proposed provision that,China imposes its national security law ndashwith extradition to the mainland ndash all Hong Kong holders of a British National Overseas passportshould be entitled to come to the UK with the right to work for at least  months is a welcome step.Of course, it would have been betterwersquod simply offered that ndash as some of us argued at the time ndash to all Hong Kong residents about  years ago, just as it would have been betterwersquod extended a similar offer to other Commonwealth citizens, rather than Theresa Mayrsquos policy of illegally deporting members of the Windrush generation. But itrsquos not just a question of it being the right thing to do it would very obviously be in the countryrsquos best interests.One result of Brexit is that opposition to immigration has fallen: according to some surveys, from about  per cent a decade ago to about  per cent now. Though I regret the end of free movement with the EU countries, it at least has the consequence that the UK can control immigration. That shouldnrsquot mean limiting it on the contrary, it should allow us to open our borders to necessary workers, and the best talent from anywhere in the world.The current population of Hong Kong, one of the wealthiest and healthiest on the planet, looks a particularly attractive prospect. But itrsquos no accident that a lump of rock in the Pearl River Delta, with no advantages other than a good natural harbour, should have become so successful.Hong Kong exists because of trade. Any place without natural resourcescan only survive through trade. As Tai-Pan, James Clavellrsquos fictionalised version of its origins, depicts it, that was initially smuggling, piracy, tea and opium.What a boon its industrious and inventive population would be to our economy. But we should go further. There is the opportunity not only to accommodate the people of Hong Kong, but to replicate the conditions that made it so successful.The obvious thing to do is to set up some new jurisdiction within the UK, but modelled on Cowperthwaitersquos principles: the Isle of Man, Gibraltar and the Channel Islands are already precedents for such a distinction. A low-tax freeport and financial centre right on our doorstep would have obvious benefits for the rest of the country, while,it were very lightly regulated, it would create housing and employment opportunities not just for immigrants, but for UK citizens.It could potentially create exactly the sort of major, galvanising transformation of the economy that would lt us out of the recession that is certain to follow our current crisis, and to provide a shot in the arm and signal of intent that ought to follow our departure from the EU. The fact that the EU would hate the idea might also be a useful point in trade negotiations.Whatrsquos more,located in the right sort of area, it could realign the whole country, balancing the disproportionate dominance of London. Ideally, for trading reasons, it should be on the coast and near a major airport. For unionist reasons, but also in the interests of geographical spread of wealth from London towards the north and west in general, it would be particularly goodit were located in Scotland.You wouldnrsquot need much space: Hong Kong island is only about  sq km, and the new free city could start off quite a bit smaller. A modest start would be to transform Millport into something more along the lines of Singapore, exempting it from UK and Scottish taxes. If that turns out to be so successful that it outgrows Great Cumbrae, the next step would be to annex Rothesay.Our columns are a  for writers to express their opinions. They do not necessarily represent the views of The Herald.Read more: Esteem for our key workers is not just a matter of income
